column1: What red wines would you suggest for someone who enjoys a velvety texture and soft tannins?,"
column2: Title
column3: Description

column2: Tenuta Sette Ponti 2007 Crognolo Sangiovese (Toscana)
column3: With a small percentage of Merlot for extra softness and plushness, this beautiful Sangiovese-based wine opens with amazing intensity, red cherry, chocolate, spice and leather. The rich, round mouthfeel would pair with creamy porcini mushroom risotto.

column2: Canneto 2007 Filippone Red (Toscana)
column3: This impressive blend of Sangiovese and Merlot offers rich softness and a smooth texture backed by ripe aromas of red fruit, cinnamon spice, chocolate and mocha. The tannins also show softness and the wine would pair with choice cuts of succulent meat.

column2: Bonacchi 2011 Molino del Piano  (Brunello di Montalcino)
column3: This medium-bodied red opens with subtle aromas suggesting underbrush, leather and pressed violet. The soft round palate offers ripe black cherry and a hint of baking spice alongside pliant tannins. It's easygoing and already approachable. Drink through 2019.

column2: Sant Agnese dei F.lli Gigli 2004 Spirto Red (Toscana)
column3: This super Tuscan blend of Merlot and Cabernet Sauvignon shows richness and softness followed by aromas of red cherry, chocolate and toasted hazelnut. The tannins are firm but smooth, and the wine would pair with game meats or spicy pork ribs.

column2: Feudo Antico 2008 Tullum Red (Abruzzo)
column3: This hearty red wine from central Italy would pair well with grilled meat or veal wrapped in sage leaves and sliced prosciutto ham. Loads of red berries are followed by notes of exotic spice, leather, tobacco and firm tannins. Drink in 3–5 more years.
column9: Can you suggest a wine from Germany?,

column2: Robert Weil 2013 Kiedrich Gräfenberg Trocken GG Riesling (Rheingau)
column3: Vivid with acidity yet deep and rich in body, this dry, voluptuous wine brings out the best of a difficult vintage for Germany. It's fresh on the palate with bright apple and pear flavors, touched with nuances of bramble, spice, pollen and caramel that add complexity to the long finish.

column2: Gunderloch 2005 Diva Spätlese Riesling (Rheinhessen)
column3: The Gunderloch wines are among the best from Rheinhessen, even their non-site-specific wines like the Diva spätlese. Aromas of bergamot, pear and fresh greens give way to ripe pineapple, citrus and herb flavors. It's fresh and zippy, offering a lot of refreshment value in an off-dry style.

column2: Weingut Georg Albrecht Schneider 2006 Niersteiner Paterberg Kabinett Riesling (Rheinhessen)
column3: A solid value in German Riesling that just misses out being a Best Buy, this wine features aromas of honey-drizzled baked apples with cinnamon and lemon juice, a refreshingly light feel on the palate and an ultraclean, persistent finish with undertones of ripe melon. Drink now–2015.

column2: Domdechant Werner 2006 Hochheimer Domdechaney Erstes Gewächs Riesling (Rheingau)
column3: Smoke and petrol notes lead off, followed up by hints of dried apricot and fresh peach. This is a thick, viscous dry Riesling, oozing with minerality that persists through the long finish. Although most German producers insist wines like this will age, why wait? Drink it over the next few years.

column2: Reichsgraf von Kesselstatt 2014 Piesporter Goldtröpfchen GG Trocken Riesling (Mosel)
column3: A standout among an excellent lineup of 2014 grosses gewächs from Reichsgraf von Kesselstatt, this gorgeously textured wine is as light as a feather, yet with a distinctly luscious cling. Dry but pentratingly fruity, it contrasts ripe peach and grapefruit flavors against laser-sharp edges of acidity and minerality. Drinks beautifully now but should continue to please well into the next decade.
column9: I enjoy bold flavors, could you recommend a robust red wine?","

column2: SOLID 2012 Proprietary Red (California)
column3: Bold, well structured and nicely dry, this wine has plenty of dark-red color, appetizing black-cherry and wild-berry aromas, and ample but not overripe fruit flavors. A full-bodied, grown-up kind of wine, it doesn't overdo anything and will be great at the dinner table.

column2: Château de Lisennes 2011 Cuvée Tradition  (Bordeaux Supérieur)
column3: This bold, fruity wine is all red berries and ripe cherry flavors. It has good juiciness, soft tannins and it will be ready to drink soon. A bright wine, with great acidity at the end.

column2: Rare NV 4 Grape Blend Red (California)
column3: Here's a good, robust red wine. It's made in a country-style, with tobacco, cherry and spice flavors and a jagged mouthfeel. Drink it with tacos and burgers.

column2: Fontanavecchia 2007 Vigna Cataratte Riserva  (Aglianico del Taburno)
column3: Here's a bold wine that opens with aromas of underbrush, tilled soil and black plum. The juicy palate delivers ripe blackberry and rich black cherry accented by cinnamon, black pepper, chocolate and licorice. This is a big wine with enveloping, velvety tannins. The only drawback here is the evident alcohol, but the fruit is delicious. This at its peak so drink soon.

column2: Leese-Fitch 2014 Firehouse Red (California)
column3: Bold and spicy, this dry wine is saturated with toasty oak and vanilla flavors over plum and prune. Made from mostly Petite Sirah and Syrah, it has medium body and a smooth texture.
column9: Can you suggest a red wine that's rich with blackberry or plum flavors?,

column2: Adega Cooperativa do Cartaxo 2013 Bridão Clássico Red (Tejo)
column3: A ripe, smooth and richly fruity wine that has a well-integrated structure. Flavors of generous blackberry and red plums are lightly touched by acidity. The wine is ready to drink.

column2: Wines & Winemakers 2008 Aguia Moura Em Vinhas Velhas Reserva Red (Douro)
column3: A powerful and concentrated wine, this shows the region's dark and tannic side. The black plum and juicy black-currant flavors shine, and wood aging has smoothed the palate, which makes it feel dense and fully mature.

column2: Stag's Leap Wine Cellars 2012 Artemis Cabernet Sauvignon (Napa Valley)
column3: A rich, full-bodied wine with small amounts of Merlot and Malbec, this offers sizable tannins that wrap themselves around dark, brooding fruit and smoky oak. Blackberry and plum intertwine around luxurious chocolate and tobacco, complementing one another on the finish.

column2: Monteviejo 2014 Festivo Malbec (Mendoza)
column3: Boisterous black plum and blackberry aromas properly announce an extra grabby palate with rock-hard tannins. This tastes like roasted plum, cassis and blackened spices. Tannic and dry as a bone on the finish, with a savory note.

column2: Colomé 2007 Reserva Malbec (Calchaquí Valley)
column3: Big, dark, sweet and jammy on the nose, with earthy, candied, sweet aromas of ripe blackberry and herbs. The palate delivers bouncy, showy acidity, while the flavors of black cherry, dark plum and chocolate are solid and rewarding. A little pruney on deeper inspection, with a leathery quality to the wine's depth. Drink now through 2013.
column9: What's a good white wine with a luscious mouthfeel and a touch of sweetness?,

column2: Charles de Fère NV Réserve Blanc de Blancs Brut Sparkling (Vin Mousseux)
column3: This smooth, creamy wine is attractively fruity with pleasant white fruit and almond flavors. The palate is soft, finishing with a hint of caramel.

column2: Banear 2006 Mamàn White (Delle Venezie)
column3: A luminous Italian white wine offersing subdued tones of stone fruit, white mineral and honey. There's an aromatic component that is reminiscent of mint and the wine is clean and easy in the mouth with a vibrant, fresh finish.

column2: Gancia NV Grand Reale White (Piedmont)
column3: Here is a sweet and fragrant dessert wine with aromas of white flower, honey and stone fruit accented by a slightly drying mineral characteristic. Firm, tonic effervescence keeps the palate refreshed even when paired with whipped cream or creamy fruit desserts.

column2: Donnafugata 2007 Chiarandà  (Contessa Entellina)
column3: This is an absolutely beautiful white wine (made from a bland of Ansonica and Chardonnay) that delivers rich and opulent tones of stone fruit, mon blossom. The wine excels in the mouth thanks to its richness and smooth creaminess.

column2: Château Bastor Lamontagne 2008 BL de Bastor-Lamontagne  (Bordeaux Blanc)
column3: This dry white shows softness and a light, creamy, gentle touch. The wine has apricot and fresh lime juice flavors, opening easily as it gets air to finish well-rounded but properly crisp.
column9: What's a fruity red wine?,

column2: Dão Sul 2009 Cortello Tinto Red (Lisboa)
column3: Fruity red berry-flavored wine, with attractive light tannins, plenty of acidity and an earthy edge. There's a touch of pepper, the finish showing fine acidity.

column2: Barton & Guestier 2011 Bistro Pinot Noir (Ile de Beauté)
column3: Soft and fruity with some sweetness, this red-fruit-flavored wine is rounded and warm, crispened by acidity.

column2: Companhia das Quintas 2006 Farizoa Red (Alentejano)
column3: Fruity and ripe, this is a spicy wine, with red cherry and berry flavors, livened by dried raisins. There is a rustic edge that puts it simply in its place, but the acidity is fine and so is the dry tannic core.

column2: Cartuxa 2014 Vinea Tinto Red (Alentejano)
column3: Made to be drunk young, this is a fruity red berry flavored wine. It has a bright crisp edge to its fruit as well as light tannins and acidity. It is quite ready to drink.

column2: Rovisco Garcia 2010 Tinto Red (Alentejano)
column3: A fruity style of red, it is made to be drunk young, possibly even lightly chilled. It has soft tannins plus a fine balance between the berry fruits and acidity that go with a warm, ripe feel. Drink now.
column9: Are there any white wines with a strong presence of pear or apple flavors?,

column2: Kamiak 2014 Unoaked Chardonnay (Columbia Valley (WA))
column3: This straightforward wine has notes of fresh apple and pear. The flavors are light in style, seeming a bit dilute.

column2: Corvidae 2013 Mirth Chardonnay (Columbia Valley (WA))
column3: This lightly aromatic wine conveys ripe red apple, pear, and star fruit. The fruit flavors are centered in a ball in the middle, offering plenty of appeal if not much complexity.

column2: Duval-Leroy 2005 Blanc de Blancs Brut Millesimé Chardonnay (Champagne)
column3: A soft, rich wine with delicious flavors of pear and red apples, lifted by pineapple acidity. It is ripe, but still young, with touches of yeast and almond. It will age well over the medium-term.

column2: Bougrier 2016 Alain de la Treille Chardonnay (Vin de France)
column3: This broad wine has apple and pear flavors and a smooth texture. It's all ripe and creamy fruit, with well-balanced acidity.

column2: Jaffelin NV Brut  (Crémant de Bourgogne)
column3: This is an attractive and fruity, creamy wine. Flavors of ripe apples and pear juice are boosted by the nutty suggestion of bottle age and by a tight, crisp acidity at the end.
column9: I'm interested in a wine from the Barossa Valley region.,

column2: Maverick 2014 Breechens Shiraz (Barossa)
column3: It's hard to believe such a wine can come from the Barossa, a region known for size and richness. But this is part of a new wave of Aussie Shiraz—medium in body and silky in style, with moderate alcohol levels. Healthy doses of oak impart notes of hickory smoke, cedar and vanilla to the plum fruit. Drink now–2025.

column2: Peter Lehmann 2014 Portrait Shiraz (Barossa Valley)
column3: This medium-bodied Shiraz represents a solid value. Sourced from 80 growers, it's meant to present a “portrait” of the Barossa region, and it delivers vanilla, plum and black olive aromas and flavors, supple tannins and a lingering mocha finish.

column2: John Duval Wines 2013 Eligo Shiraz (Barossa Valley)
column3: Full bodied, creamy and lush, this is a prototypical Barossa Valley Shiraz from a longtime master of the variety. Smoke, cedar, mulberry and eucalyptus notes mingle easily on the nose, while savory notes of roasted meat and dried herb blend seamlessly into the fruit, ending long, velvety and rich.

column2: St Hallett 2008 Gamekeeper's Shiraz (Barossa)
column3: Full bodied and supple, this nicely balanced Barossa Shiraz shows that value still exists even in big-name regions of Australia. Intense blueberry and spice aromas give way to mixed berries and vanilla on the palate, and if it's not overly complex, it's a still a concentrated mouthful of Shiraz at a bargain price.

column2: Glaetzer 2013 Bishop Shiraz (Barossa Valley)
column3: This has gone up in price over the years, but it's still a solid, relatively affordable example of Barossa Valley Shiraz. This is youthful and edgy, with meaty, savory notes accenting mixed berries and a hint of mint. The finish is a bit chewy right now, but mouthcoating and long.
column9: I'd like a sparkling wine, excluding Merlot.","

column2: Ruggeri & C. NV Argeo Brut  (Prosecco Treviso)
column3: Here's a crisp, no-frills sparkler that offers yellow apple and pear flavors. It's invigorating, with brisk acidity and vivacious bubbles.

column2: Case Paolin NV Brut  (Asolo Prosecco Superiore)
column3: Simple tones of white fruit and crushed stone mark this sparkler. A touch of softness is offered by the creamy quality of the wine's effervescence.

column2: Cembra NV Ororosso Dosaggio Zero Chardonnay (Trento)
column3: Here's a stunning sparkling wine made in the classic method, with no added dosage. It offers citrus, melon, apple, stone fruit, minerality and walnut notes. The creamy palate is supported by crisp freshness and finishes bone-dry.

column2: Merotto NV Colbelo Extra Dry  (Conegliano Valdobbiadene Prosecco Superiore)
column3: Here's a simple sparkling wine that delivers subtle tones of peach and stone fruit with a thin and transparent appearance. This expression does a nice job of presenting sweet fruit tones against fresh acidity.

column2: Progettidivini NV Extra Dry  (Conegliano Valdobbiadene Prosecco Superiore)
column3: This bright sparkling wine delivers a touch of sassy spice in front of softer aromas of stone fruit, white flower and dried herb. Pair this with cocktail snacks, like potato chips or green olives.
column9: Are there any red wines with a touch of earthiness and cherry undertones?,

column2: Bolsignano 2009 Grazia  (Brunello di Montalcino)
column3: This earthy wine opens with aromas of meat juices, baking spices and black fruit together with notes of leather and balsam. The rich palate delivers dark red cherry layered with mint and a tad of milk chocolate alongside dusty tannins. It' well balanced and should age moderately well. Drink 2016–2024.

column2: La Gerla 2008 Gli Angeli Riserva  (Brunello di Montalcino)
column3: Earthy aromas suggest tilled soil, leather, prune, balsam and dried cherries marinated in spirits. The palate offers ripe black cherry accented with sensations of white pepper, cinnamon, fig, black tea and a hint of chocolate. It has assertive but polished tannins and nice depth, but it already seems fully developed. Drink 2015–2023.

column2: Collosorbo 2010 Riserva  (Brunello di Montalcino)
column3: Here's an earthy wine that opens with aromas of scorched earth, leather, truffle, raspberry compote and a note of cured meat. The chewy palate offers mature Morello cherry, grilled herb, coffee, clove and anise while firm, ripe tannins provide the framework. A tobacco note closes the finish. Drink 2018–2028.

column2: I Custodi 2013 Pistus Rosso  (Etna)
column3: Here's an earthy wine that opens with aromas of leafy underbrush, porcini mushroom, game, mature black plum and dark berry. The palate delivers juicy dark berry, toast and allspice alongside assertive, drying tannins and a hint of licorice.

column2: COS 2011 Delle Fontane  (Cerasuolo di Vittoria Classico)
column3: Earthy and delicious, this soulful red opens with aromas of sun-baked soil, leather, ripe black fruit, dark spice and a funky but pleasant whiff of game. The round, smooth tastes of juicy blackberry, wild cherry, cinnamon, black olive, cured meat and mineral framed in silky tannins. It's already enjoyable, with depth and balance but it will age well for another decade or more. Drink through 2026.
column9: Is there a wine that is not too oaky?,

column2: Beringer 2004 St. Helena Home Vineyard Cabernet Sauvignon (Napa Valley)
column3: There's a softness to this dry wine. It's forward and rich in currants and smoky oak, but could use greater acidity. The tannins also seem a little ungainly, although they could mellow out in a few years.

column2: Château Les Bertrands 2015 Nectar Des Bertrands  (Blaye Côtes de Bordeaux)
column3: New wood aromas lead this toasty wine that has spice, high toast flavors and the smallest hint of fruit. If the producer had not been so enthusiastic with the oak, this could have been a good wine.

column2: Quivet Cellars 2007 Kenefick Ranch Cabernet Sauvignon (Napa Valley)
column3: This 100% Cabernet tastes way too oaky. Vanilla cream and caramel dominate the blackberries and black currants, giving it a woody sweetness. The question is, will it age out? The classic answer is that a wine that tastes unbalanced when young most likely always will.

column2: Château de Camarsac 2011 Prince Noir  (Bordeaux Supérieur)
column3: This wine is too toasty for its own good. It has dark tannins, high spice and bitter toastiness. There is a soapy aftertaste that only just hints at fruit.

column2: Malesan 2000 Rouge  (Bordeaux)
column3: Despite coming from a universally hailed vintage, this generic Bordeaux is still weedy, herbal and lean. But it also has decent cassis and cherry fruit, some tasty vanilla and cinnamon notes from oak aging, and a tart, dry finish. It's light, but it hasn't been dumbed down for the mass market.
column9: I'm looking for a red wine with a good balance between oakiness and fruitiness. Any recommendations?,

column2: Tassi 2004 Aquabona Red (Toscana)
column3: This bold, spicy wine will appeal to those who love modern reds with thick concentration and lingering oak-driven flavors. Black cherry, prune and ripe blueberry do come into view, but the protagonist here is the oak. The wine has chewy tannins, good length on the finish and would pair with grilled meats or aged cheeses.

column2: Leone de Castris 2005 Riserva Red (Salice Salentino)
column3: This is an oak-heavy red wine from Southern Italy that is embellished by aromas of vanilla, toast and spice that sit heavy over a rich core of ripe fruit. The wine is firm and streamlined in the mouth and offers a hint of sour cherry on the close. This vintage represents a huge jump forward in quality compared to 2004.

column2: Donatella Cinelli Colombini 2004 Fattoria del Colle Cenerentola Red (Orcia)
column3: This red has a wide and broad personality that encompasses aromas of black fruit, leather and tobacco. There's less fresh fruit here: the wine definitely focuses on oak-driven tones, but it is lively enough to pair with roasted meat or dishes that require a touch of juicy succulence.

column2: Tagaris 2007 Frank Chiullino Chef Blend Red Red (Columbia Valley (WA))
column3: This red wine, named for the chef at the winery restaurant, is fruity and high-toned, with lots of cherry and berry flavor. All neutral oak, soft tannins, ready to drink.

column2: Red Theory 2012 Winemaker's Red (Columbia Valley (WA))
column3: A straightforward wine with light notes of red and blue berries along with oak accents.
column9: I'm interested in trying a red wine with a bold and peppery character. Any ideas?,

column2: Tassi 2004 Aquabona Red (Toscana)
column3: This bold, spicy wine will appeal to those who love modern reds with thick concentration and lingering oak-driven flavors. Black cherry, prune and ripe blueberry do come into view, but the protagonist here is the oak. The wine has chewy tannins, good length on the finish and would pair with grilled meats or aged cheeses.

column2: Donatella Cinelli Colombini 2004 Fattoria del Colle Cenerentola Red (Orcia)
column3: This red has a wide and broad personality that encompasses aromas of black fruit, leather and tobacco. There's less fresh fruit here: the wine definitely focuses on oak-driven tones, but it is lively enough to pair with roasted meat or dishes that require a touch of juicy succulence.

column2: Crane Brothers 2005 Crane Ranch Vineyard Brodacious Red (Napa Valley)
column3: Here's a powerfully fruity Napa red wine to drink tonight with roasts, cheeses, or just a nice burger. It's full-bodied, dry and rich in tannins, with black currant, anise, dark chocolate and smoky oak flavors. A blend of Bordeaux varieties and Syrah.

column2: Cantina Santadi 2011 Noras  (Carignano del Sulcis)
column3: This robust red opens with aromas of ripe black-skinned fruit, scorched earth and dark cooking spice. The warm, forward palate offers black cherry marinated in spirits and licorice accompanied by ripe, velvety tannins. Unfortunately, the heat of searing alcohol throws it off balance and dominates the palate.

column2: Crane Brothers 2006 Brodatious Crane Ranch Vineyard Red (Napa Valley)
column3: A Bordeaux blend with a little Syrah, this red wine is dry and rich in currant and cedar flavors. But it's a little sharp and green in tannins, with a tart mouthfeel. A good steak will help, but it's not really an ager, so drink up.
column9: What's a light-bodied white wine?,

column2: Adalia 2015 Singan  (Soave)
column3: Here's a light-bodied casual wine that has subdued aromas suggesting white flower, orchard fruit and a hint of almond. You can find traces of the nose on the extremely simple diluted palate.

column2: Producta Vignobles 2015 Mission St. Vincent  (Bordeaux Blanc)
column3: Light and fruity, the wine is dilute and gently textured. It is ready to drink.

column2: Banear 2006 Mamàn White (Delle Venezie)
column3: A luminous Italian white wine offersing subdued tones of stone fruit, white mineral and honey. There's an aromatic component that is reminiscent of mint and the wine is clean and easy in the mouth with a vibrant, fresh finish.

column2: Dominio IV 2012 Mulberry Street Vitae Springs Vineyard Pinot Noir (Willamette Valley)
column3: The lightest wine in the winery's well-crafted lineup, this marries grapefruity acidity to tart cherry fruit. It's nicely balanced, airy and a pleasure to drink.

column2: Château Bastor Lamontagne 2008 BL de Bastor-Lamontagne  (Bordeaux Blanc)
column3: This dry white shows softness and a light, creamy, gentle touch. The wine has apricot and fresh lime juice flavors, opening easily as it gets air to finish well-rounded but properly crisp.
column9: What's a bold white wine?,

column2: Maison Champy 2006 Les Grands Charrons  (Meursault)
column3: A big, fat, spicy wine flavored with white fruits and laced with crisp acidity. It is full and opulent, but not extravagantly so, the acidity cutting through richness, leaving yellow fruits and some toast.

column2: Larmandier-Bernier NV Latitude Extra Brut Chardonnay (Champagne)
column3: Although it's not indicated on the label, this is a Blanc de Blancs from Chardonnay. It is warm and ripe, with a soft texture allied to fresh acidity. Orange and lemon zest give a great lift to this rounded wine.

column2: Trabucco 2008 16 Marzo White (Falerno del Massico)
column3: This is an herbal, floral white wine with aromas that span from dried hay to pungent lemon blossom. It seems to give the best of itself on the bouquet, because in the mouth, this wine is fresh, compact and very easygoing.

column2: Xavier Monnot 2006 Les Chevalières  (Meursault)
column3: A powerfully rich wine that brings in delicious white and yellow fruit flavors. It is unctuous, rounded, made richer with toast then given a boost by a streak of fresh citrus acidity. Good, plump white Burgundy.

column2: Domaine Sangouard-Guyot 2010 Au Brûlé  (Saint-Véran)
column3: A simple, white fruited wine. Its texture is light, bright, the acidity coming from a touch of wood and apple and cream fruits. Easy drinking, ready to go.
column9: What would be a good wine for a tasting event?,

column2: Batzella 2009 Digià  (Bolgheri)
column3: The wine is redolent of bright blueberry and cherry with a tonic, youthful berry feel in the mouth. This easy blend of Cabernet Sauvignon (60%), Syrah and Cabernet Franc would make the perfect companion to pizza or pasta.

column2: Bellini 2008 VYD Red (Toscana)
column3: This is a very informal and easygoing red table wine that would taste great with pizza. It opens with a bright ruby color and shows aromas of cherry, raspberry and toasted almond.

column2: Domaines Lapalu 2009 La Patache  (Médoc)
column3: A rich wine laden with juicy blackberry fruits and wood tannins, lapping up the ripe vintage. Soft and ready to drink.

column2: Duca del Frassino 2009 Merlot and Pinot Noir 3 liter BIB Red (Venezie)
column3: A friendly and informal blend of Merlot and Pinot Noir, this 3-liter boxed wine from northern Italy would make a perfect companion at outdoor picnics or baseball games. It's a light and refreshing wine with crisp flavors of red berries and pressed violets.

column2: Badia a Coltibuono 2009 Cancelli Red (Toscana)
column3: A straight-shooting blend of Sangiovese and Syrah for picnics or weekends away with friends. The wine goes down easy, and offers fresh cherry and blueberry flavors along the way.
column9: What's a good red wine that's both fruit-forward and has a spicy finish?,

column2: Adega Cooperativa do Cartaxo 2010 Coudel Mor Red (Tejo)
column3: A young, fruity wine with soft tannins and juicy berry fruits. It is forward, very approachable, and is ready to drink with pasta or spicy food.

column2: Wines & Winemakers 2011 Companhia das Lezírias Catapereiro Escolha Red (Tejo)
column3: A big, ripe and spicy wine that is full of red fruit notes and gentle tannins. It is open and accessible, its fruit juiciness already a pleasure to taste. There is fresh acidity on the finish. Drink now through 2019.

column2: Wines & Winemakers 2011 Companhia das Lezírias Catapereiro Red (Tejo)
column3: This is a spicy wine that is full of juicy red-berry fruit notes. It is soft and gentle, with a core of dry tannins that gives the wine structure. Young and fruity, it is ready to drink, but will also age. Drink until 2018.

column2: Kuentz-Bas 2013 Tradition Gewurztraminer (Alsace)
column3: This fresh and fruity wine is soft with gentle spice. It has a crisp side as well, making for an easy, ready-to-drink wine that is well balanced.

column2: Biecher & Schaal 2013 Steinert Grand Cru Gewurztraminer (Alsace)
column3: This is a forward, fruity and spicy wine. It is sweet and soft, with the lightest hint of acidity to give some freshness at the finish. Lychees and mangos combine easily with the attractive pinch of pepper at the end.
column9: Suggest a wine from a winery known for its award-winning practices.,

column2: Thomas George 2007 Allen Vineyard Pinot Noir (Russian River Valley)
column3: The vineyard is great and famous, yet the wine doesn't exhibit its best qualities. It's soft and rather direct, with flavors of cherries, raspberries, orange rind and cola, accented with sweet smoky oak. Good and silky, but could come from anywhere.

column2: Marchesi Antinori 2009 Marchese Antinori Riserva  (Chianti Classico)
column3: Here's a polished wine made from a blend of 90% Sangiovese and 10% Cabernet Sauvignon. It offers aromas of red berry, blue flower and cedar with a hint of toasted oak. The concentrated flavors include black cherry, exotic spice and a hint of chocolate. Soft with smoothed tannins, this is already approachable.

column2: Patz & Hall 2014 Chenoweth Ranch Pinot Noir (Russian River Valley)
column3: This lovely, memorable wine from a fantastically farmed site is grippy in cherry and pomegranate with a backbone of integrated oak. Crunchy in texture, it shines in floral aromatics and a balanced body weight that's fruity and complex.

column2: Tommasi 2012 Poggio al Tufo Rompicollo Red (Toscana)
column3: This simple but inviting wine is made from a blend of 60% Sangiovese and 40% Cabernet Sauvignon. The bright palate boasts sour cherry, red currants and light note of white pepper alongside fresh acidity. It's perfect for everyday fare.

column2: Gary Farrell 2014 Rochioli-Allen Vineyards Pinot Noir (Russian River Valley)
column3: From two of the most coveted sites in the appellation, this wine showcases an elegant ripeness and rapturous relationship to fruit. Dried sage and forest overtones complement concentrated flavors of fig, orange and dried cherry. It offers ample structure and is beautifully put together.
column9: Can you recommend a red wine that's elegant and well-structured?,

column2: Alente 2009 Trincadeira-Aragonez Red (Alentejo)
column3: An elegant wine that slides easily over the palate. Its red berry flavors have a firm edge that stiffens the initial softness. Its tannins and acidity make this a serious, food-friendly wine that could age.

column2: Casa Santos Lima 2005 Palha-Canas Red (Estremadura)
column3: An elegant, understated wine that shows balanced red fruits, vanilla and touches of chocolate. Its attractiveness lies in the balance, with structure and acidity keeping the exuberant fruit flavors in check. Worth aging for 1–2 years.

column2: Quinta da Alorna 2009 Portal da Aguia Red (Tejo)
column3: A full-bodied, rich wine that combines extra juiciness with delicious red-berry fruits. It is structured while being immediately attractive. It's a great wine to go with pasta dishes.

column2: Terra d'Alter 2009 Special Selection Red (Alentejano)
column3: An elegant wine, its red fruits laced with firm yet subtle tannins. It is finished with acidity, a balanced layer of wood. The wine, with its serious structure, needs 2–3 years aging.

column2: Quinta Monteiro de Matos 2014 Terras de Paul Red (Tejo)
column3: The wine has structured fruit along with red berry flavors. It is otherwise soft, easy, and ready to drink with a crisp finish.
column9: Can you recommend a red wine with velvety tannins and a long finish?,

column2: Feudo Antico 2008 Tullum Red (Abruzzo)
column3: This hearty red wine from central Italy would pair well with grilled meat or veal wrapped in sage leaves and sliced prosciutto ham. Loads of red berries are followed by notes of exotic spice, leather, tobacco and firm tannins. Drink in 3–5 more years.

column2: Adega Cooperativa do Cartaxo 2011 Bridão Clássico Red (Tejo)
column3: Great bursts of red fruits come strongly through the tannins of this powerful and structured wine. It's fruity and ripe, although an herbal element suggests a more green aspect. Tannins need to finish softening, so wait until 2015.

column2: Caves Transmontanas 2012 Quanta Terra Grande Reserva Red (Douro)
column3: Full of red fruits and generous tannins, this is an immediately attractive wine. The red-berry fruits are balanced by good acidity and a crisp aftertaste. Drink from 2017 to allow the tannins to soften further.

column2: Tenuta Monteti 2006 Monteti Red (Toscana)
column3: This thick, juicy, inky wine (with a large component of Petit Verdot) would pair with aged cheese or pecorino. The wine is still young (let it age five more years) with firm, sticky tannins and loads of blackberry and plum cake on the long finish.

column2: Podere Sapaio 2007 Sapaio  (Bolgheri Superiore)
column3: This is a lovely, rich wine with mature red berry tones followed by sharp mineral definition and bright aromas of fresh Indian spice. The wine is dense and decadent and could stand up to beef tenderloin with balsamic reduction.
column9: Are there any white wines with a pronounced peach or apricot flavor?,

column2: L. Tramier & Fils 2015 Collection  (Pouilly-Fuissé)
column3: Apricot and peach fruits dominate this creamy, soft wine. It's smooth, lightly toasty and ready to drink.

column2: Castello di Corbara 2013 Podere Il Caio  (Orvieto Classico Superiore)
column3: Apricot and savory herb aromas lead the nose on this sophisticated white. The palate shows a core of concentrated yellow peach and pear accented with a light note of fennel. Fresh acidity adds brightness and makes for a pristine finish.

column2: Domaine Leflaive 2009 Clavoillon Premier Cru  (Puligny-Montrachet)
column3: A deliciously fruity wine, its bright apricot, pineapple and peach flavors open and generous. Of course, there is a more serious core of structure, lemon zest and dryness to promise aging. At the end, though, fruit and a light toastiness give immediate pleasure.

column2: Château Philippe-le-Hardi 2010 En Vesvau  (Saint-Aubin)
column3: This is an attractive, fruity wine, with citrus and creamed apple flavors. It is light and fragrant, with apricots and white fruits that pair with the crisp finish.

column2: Conte d'Attimis-Maniago 2010 Casoli Maniago Pinot Grigio (Colli Orientali del Friuli)
column3: This is an easy white wine with balanced acidity. There's a spicy note of crushed clove or exotic spice at the start that is smoothed out by softer aromas of peach cobbler and lemon mousse.
column9: Is there a wine that is not too dry?,

column2: Beringer 2004 St. Helena Home Vineyard Cabernet Sauvignon (Napa Valley)
column3: There's a softness to this dry wine. It's forward and rich in currants and smoky oak, but could use greater acidity. The tannins also seem a little ungainly, although they could mellow out in a few years.

column2: Domaine du Claouset 2011 Réserve  (Bordeaux Supérieur)
column3: A hard and tannic wine, with too much dryness for pleasure. It's not likely to soften enough to balance out.

column2: Château des Tourtes 2014 Prestige  (Blaye Côtes de Bordeaux)
column3: From a 17-acre Merlot-dominated vineyard, this is a dry wine, where the tannins dominate the fruit. The wine has a bitter edge from too much extraction. The hints of fruit are not quite enough.

column2: Château Fongrave 2005 Elevé en Fûts de Chêne  (Bordeaux)
column3: A smooth, rich wine that wears its lightness and freshness with grace. There are plenty of crisp black currant and plum skin flavors, along with wood tannins that add spice and dryness. Not hugely rich, but attractively fresh.

column2: Black & White 2006 Topanga Vineyards Cabernet Sauvignon (Napa Valley)
column3: A good, sound wine to drink now. It's nicely dry and rich in tannins, with a burst of acidity. The cherry, blackberry and raspberry flavors are a bit jammy.
column9: Can you suggest a wine from France?,

column2: Lionel Osmin & Cie 2010 Villa la Réserve Malbec (Vin de France)
column3: Although this is labeled Vin de France, this is effectively a Cahors wine. It's soft and rounded, with tannins that are already integrated already into blackberry jam flavors. Rich, with a hint of dried fruit, this is ready to drink in a year.

column2: Monmousseau NV Brut Etoile Sparkling (Vin Mousseux)
column3: Although the producer is based in the Loire, it sources grapes for this wine from other regions of France as well as locally. That gives the wine perhaps a richer, softer, less fresh character. It is an easy, apple-fruity wine with light acidity.

column2: Henry Marionnet 2011 Domaine de la Charmoise Gamay (Touraine)
column3: Fruity wine from one of the best produces of Gamay in the Loire. Cherry flavors, bright acidity and just a touch of tannin on this youthful wine.

column2: Georges Duboeuf 2015 Domaine de Roche Noire  (Moulin-à-Vent)
column3: From an small estate that also has vines in Chénas and Saint-Amour, this is a firmly tannic wine that also has attractive juicy red-berry fruits. The wine, still young, will repay aging allowing it to broaden out with rich fruit and a soft texture. Drink this cru from late 2017.

column2: Bailly-Lapierre NV Paul Delane Réserve Brut  (Crémant de Bourgogne)
column3: Grapes from the small village of Saint-Bris le Vineux west of Chablis are used in this attractive, crisp and fruity wine. It has a strongly mineral tang to its fruitiness with lemon zest and intense acidity. The aftertaste is softer, rounded and ready to drink.
column9: Looking for a wine that is hand-harvested.,

column2: Purple Hands 2013 Freedom Hill Vineyard Pinot Noir (Willamette Valley)
column3: This well-regarded vineyard shines here, ripening the grapes fully in a challenging vintage. Raspberry and cherry flavors are joined with a streak of red licorice. Among the 2013s from Purple Hands, this is likely to be the longest lived.

column2: Chehalem 2011 Ridgecrest Vineyards Pinot Noir (Ribbon Ridge)
column3: Proving that exceptional wines can be (and were) made in this cool, light vintage, this estate-grown selection is both elegant and complex. Flavors of mixed wild berries, a streak of tea, a whiff of peach and compelling balance carry it through an extended finish.

column2: King Estate 2013 Antiquum Vineyards Pinot Noir (Willamette Valley)
column3: This delivers handmade, natural wine character. It's a limited release from King's “Vineyard Designate” series, and a bold, deep, supple and smooth one at that. Red plum, citrus peel, a thread of caramel and a whiff of chocolate combine in a wine that should drink well through 2026.

column2: Goodfellow 2012 Bishop Creek Vineyard Pinot Noir
column3: Sourced from 25-year-old vines, this shows traces of dried leaf, along with tart rhubarb and wild cherry fruit. A light dusting of cinnamon and coffee completes a wine that is balanced throughout, medium in length, and finished with an elegant flair.

column2: Lumos 2013 Temperance Hill Vineyard Pinot Noir (Eola-Amity Hills)
column3: This is certified organic, from one of Oregon's leading vineyards. Somewhat muted in this cool, wet vintage, it's nonetheless a sturdy effort with a potent herbal component. The stiff red fruits conjure up a tart cranberry and cherry mix.
column9: Recommend a wine with hints of citrus.,

column2: Patriarche Père et Fils 2016 Les Charmes  (Mâcon-Lugny)
column3: This soft, light wine has hints of citrus and acidity. It is fruity, crisp and bright with orange zest at the end. Drink now.

column2: Vignerons de Tutiac 2016 Carrelet d'Estuaire  (Bordeaux Blanc)
column3: A pure citrus-flavored wine, this is refreshing and light. Its crispness will soften over the next few months, but drink now for the forward fruitiness.

column2: Labouré-Roi 2006 Les Chevaliers  (Meursault)
column3: A soft, rounded wine, with spice and toast and a cushion of plump yellow fruit. Almonds and mandarin oranges fit well together with the fine acidity.

column2: Domaine Sangouard-Guyot 2014 Terroirs  (Pouilly-Fuissé)
column3: This citrus-laden wine shows its fresh fruits right up front. It is bright, crisp and full of lime and lemon flavors. Spiciness adds extra interest. Drink now.

column2: Georges Duboeuf 2013 Domaine des Chènevières  (Mâcon-Villages)
column3: This simple wine has some attractive citrus fruit. It is light, bright with plenty of acidity to keep it all fresh. It should be drunk now.
column9: Recommend a wine with hints of cherry.,

column2: Cubanisimo Vineyards 2012 Rumba Pinot Noir (Willamette Valley)
column3: This is a light and cheery wine, with cherry and raspberry fruit. It suggests hard candy with a hint of the barnyard; forward, round and fruity.

column2: Bergström 2010 Shea Vineyard Pinot Noir
column3: Bright cherry fruit is set against a backdrop of clean earth, while the young tannins are firm and focused. The wine carries balanced suggestions of leaf and herb, and will surely benefit from further bottle age.

column2: Castelgiocondo 2012 Campo ai Sassi  (Rosso di Montalcino)
column3: This straightforward, simple wine brings together sensations of violet, red cherry and light baking spices. The warm, forward palate finishes on a sweet note of cherry extract. It's made to be enjoyed young and will pair well with hearty pasta dishes.

column2: Siduri 2006 Muirfield Vineyard Pinot Noir (Willamette Valley)
column3: Cherries jump out at you, a dense compendium of fruit set against iron and earth. The wine is a bit austere, tight; it may need decanting. But it's got good concentration and spice, and flavor that keeps on running through a long finish.

column2: Benton-Lane 2010 Estate Pinot Noir (Willamette Valley)
column3: A pretty, inviting nose suggests sweet cherry and cherry blossom. On the light-bodied palate, the wine shows earthiness. It's pleasant and just right for near-term enjoyment.
column9: Can you suggest a wine from Argentina?,

column2: Ramos-Pinto 2011 Duas Quintas Reserva Branco White (Douro)
column3: Ramos-Pinto's two estates of Bons Aires and Ervamoira provide the grapes for this fruity, smooth-textured white wine. While this selection reflects the warmth of the Douro, it also shows great citrusy freshness and a crisp finish. Ready to drink.

column2: Casca Wines 2015 Monte Cascas Colheita Red (Alentejano)
column3: This smooth, rich wine exudes southern warmth. The blend of Touriga Nacional, Aragonez and Alicante Bouschet gives a ripe, dark-colored wine dominated by black fruits. Tannins and acidity provide happy support. Drink now.

column2: Wine & Soul 2005 Pintas Character Red (Douro)
column3: A second wine from the Pintas range of Jorge Serodio and Sandra Tavares, this is a big, forward wine, pushing out ripe red plum and strawberry fruits. It's almost sweet in its ripeness.

column2: Herdade do Esporão 2014 Arco do Esporão Red (Alentejo)
column3: Touriga Nacional, Syrah and Aragonez (aka Tempranillo) give this wine a fine balance between structure and fruitiness. While the alcohol suggests power, in fact it's the freshness and attractive red berry fruits that dominate. The wine is soft and ready to drink.

column2: Casca Wines 2015 Cascas Winemaker Selection Red (Lisboa)
column3: Syrah, Castelão and Aragonez go into the blend of this rich juicy wine. It is so soft and ripe, just hinting at tannins and with red-berry fruit. The wine is round and smooth, ready to drink.
column9: Suggest a wine from a winery known for its sustainable practices.,

column2: Château de Lavernette 2014 Maison du Villard  (Pouilly-Fuissé)
column3: Crisp and young, this wine, from 50-year-old vines, is tangy and strongly mineral in texture. It is full of fresh fruit that reflects the of organic and biodynamic farming. The green fruits will fill out as it ages. Drink from 2017.

column2: Jean-Marc Brocard 2005 Domaine de la Boissoneuse  (Chablis)
column3: From a vineyard run on biodynamic principles, this wine boasts good, fresh fruit, with great green, crisp acidity and green plum intensity. It's very lively and fresh, but full-bodied.

column2: Domaine Fouassier 2014 Les Chasseignes  (Sancerre)
column3: Made from vines between 20 and 40 years old, this wine is both fresh and ripe. Apple as well as citrus flavors give it a tangy streak. Made from organic and biodynamically grown grapes, it is all fruit, bright and with an attractive, perfumed aftertaste.

column2: Domaine Fouassier 2015 Le Clos de Bannon  (Sancerre)
column3: Like all wines from this producer, the fruit from this five-acre vineyard has been grown biodynamically. That explains both the clean lines of the wine and its beautiful ripe fruitiness. The yellow fruits and generous texture are deliciously full in the mouth. Drink this fine wine from 2018.

column2: Domaine de la Croix Senaillet 2014 Sur la Carrière  (Saint-Véran)
column3: This lively, crisp wine comes from a less than an acre of organically grown vines. It has big lemon and green-apple flavors as well as intense acidity that gives a juicy character. With its youthful freshness, it could do with a few more months to soften. Drink from 2017.
column9: I'm searching for a white wine that's zesty with grapefruit or lemon zest notes. Any suggestions?,

column2: Viña Casablanca 2010 Cefiro Reserva Sauvignon Blanc (Casablanca Valley)
column3: Citrus aromas are familiar. Lively and zesty in the mouth, with refreshing acidity. Orange and passion fruit lead the palate, which transitions to grapefruit. Crisp on the finish. Good for an everyday white wine.

column2: Santa Carolina 2017 Reserva Leyda Estate Sauvignon Blanc (Leyda Valley)
column3: Punchy aromas of grapefruit and jalapeño form the greeting on this lean but refreshing wine. A straightforward palate offers zesty acidity, while flavors of white pepper, sea salt, grapefruit and lime lead straight through the finish.

column2: Netzl 2016 Classic Grüner Veltliner (Carnuntum)
column3: Grapefruit spiciness and a touch of yeast show on the nose of this wine. The palate revolves around zesty grapefruit flavors, its concentration and juiciness leading to a tingling, refreshing finish that's wonderfully clean.

column2: F X Pichler 2014 Loibner Klostersatz Federspiel Grüner Veltliner (Wachau)
column3: If you could get an essence of grapefruit peel with edges of savory herbs and tingling white pepper, this wine would be it. This is wonderfully bracing and fresh yet concentrated, so there is tone and muscle but slenderness, too. Totally sleek and exhilarating now, will open up through 2019.

column2: Sepp Moser 2013 Von den Terrassen Grüner Veltliner (Kremstal)
column3: Texture and spice are the main features of this concentrated white with citrus zest on the palate. The aromatics still need to wake up; with time, they will shine. For now, grapefruit zest will suffice.
column9: Can you recommend a red wine that's velvety with a hint of mocha or coffee notes?,

column2: O•S Winery 2006 Red Wine Red (Washington)
column3: This inexpensive red wine has muscle and depth. It's chocolaty, rich and loaded with ripe, supple fruits and smooth caramel. There is plenty of coffee flavor, a sweet and broad mid-palate, and a simple but satisfying finish.

column2: Ryan Patrick 2012 Rock Island Red (Wahluke Slope)
column3: A blend of Merlot (58%), Syrah (35%), Petite Sirah (5%) and Primitivo, this hedonistic wine offers appealing suggestions of coffee, vanilla and cherry. Ripe, silky soft milk chocolate flavors finish warm.

column2: Helix 2005 Pomatia Red Wine Red (Columbia Valley (WA))
column3: Supple and scented with a sweet mix of fruit, coffee and mocha, this expressive red blend (53% Cabernet Sauvignon, 31% Merlot, 8% Cab Franc, 8% Syrah) tastes of bright black cherry fruit, coffee grounds, some grainy tannins and a long finish that brings in pepper, spice and chocolate. Very accessible and full-flavored, it is built for immediate drinking rather than cellaring.

column2: Ornellaia 2014 Le Volte Red (Toscana)
column3: An easy-drinking blend of Merlot, Sangiovese and Cabernet Sauvignon, this opens with aromas of red berry, toast, herb and roasted coffee bean. The soft palate offers black cherry, mocha and a hint of coffee alongside bright acidity and silky tannins. Drink now.

column2: Rocca delle Macìe 2010 Sergio Zingarelli Gran Selezione  (Chianti Classico)
column3: Aromas of espresso, mocha, spiced plum and vanilla lead the nose on this concentrated wine. The palate delivers dark cherry, coffee bean, toast and cooking spice alongside firm tannins. Drink 2016–2022.
column9: I prefer white wines with a lively acidity and a hint of green apple or pear. Any suggestions?,

column2: Bigi 2014 Secco  (Orvieto Classico Superiore)
column3: This pleasant white offers delicate aromas of citrus blossom and orchard fruit. The easygoing palate has green apple and peach alongside bright acidity. It would work well for everyday occasions or informal parties.

column2: Château de Fuissé 2006 Les Morats  (Saint-Véran)
column3: This lively, crisply acidic wine hints at toast, but goes much more for a delicious citrus character. There's a great freshness to the wine, showing some pear flavors and a fine edge of apple skins.

column2: La Vis 2014 Ritratti Pinot Grigio (Trentino)
column3: Fresh and fruity, this lively white offers aromas and flavors of green Anjou pear, Granny Smith apple and white peach. Zesty acidity gives it a crisp, tangy finish.

column2: Firriato 2016 Le Sabbie dell'Etna Bianco  (Etna)
column3: This wine's white flower, apple, pear and almond aromas carry over to its medium-bodied palate, along with a hint of citrus peel. It's linear and fresh, with bright acidity and a saline note on the close.

column2: Collavini 2013 Villa Canlungo Pinot Grigio (Collio)
column3: This lively wine is loaded with sensations of spring wildflowers, tart green apple, pear and nectarine. Crisp acidity gives a refreshing finish. Enjoy this as an apéritif or pair it with summer salads.
column9: Are there any white wines with a pronounced tropical fruit character like pineapple or mango?,

column2: Cantina Altarocca 2014 Arcosesto  (Orvieto Classico Superiore)
column3: Tropical fruit and peach aromas take center stage on this bright wine. The round, friendly palate doles out white peach, green apple and passion fruit alongside lively acidity.

column2: Barone Montalto 2013 Grillo-Sauvignon White (Terre Siciliane)
column3: Tropical fruit and citrus lead the nose on this lively white. The palate offers passion fruit, nectarine zest and white peach alongside crisp acidity that gives a clean finish.

column2: Principe Pallavicini 2014 Poggio Verde  (Frascati Superiore)
column3: This lively white features aromas of tropical fruit, citrus and white flower.s The bright, round palate doles out fresh peach, juicy pineapple and crisp apple alongside zesty acidity.

column2: Viña Casas Patronales 2010 Reserva Privada Chardonnay (Limarí Valley)
column3: With straw and white-fruit aromas, this tropical-leaning Chardonnay is ripe on the nose. In the mouth, it's dense and tropical in nature, with melon, mango, papaya and green herb flavors. It's chunky on the finish, so drink now.

column2: La Palma 2002 Estate Bottled Chardonnay (Cachapoal Valley)
column3: Pineapple and other tropical fruits comprise the simple, straightforward nose. Pear and tangerine flavors come across sharp, as does the finish. The wine is a bit edgy and lean on its own.
column9: What white wines would you suggest for someone who enjoys a clean, refreshing taste?","

column2: Zonin 2002 Classico  (Soave)
column3: An immediately attractive, quaffable wine with clean, fresh flavors. This is a light, fresh wine designed to go with summer foods.

column2: Corvo 2010 Fiore White (Sicilia)
column3: Here's an easy, no-fuss white wine to pair with rice salad or grilled vegetables. Citrus, almond blossom and stone fruit are capped by a slightly sweet feel in the mouth.

column2: Bigi 2014 Secco  (Orvieto Classico Superiore)
column3: This pleasant white offers delicate aromas of citrus blossom and orchard fruit. The easygoing palate has green apple and peach alongside bright acidity. It would work well for everyday occasions or informal parties.

column2: Domaines Bunan 2014 Le Petit Rouvière Rosé (Mediterranée)
column3: Light, crisp and fruity, with a touch of vanilla, this simple, fresh wine is ready to drink. Rounded fruit and a tangy aftertaste complete an attractive wine.

column2: Monte del Frá 2005 Cà del Magro  (Custoza Superiore)
column3: One of the most attractive aspects of this fresh white blend is its structure: The wine is silky and smooth and seemingly weightless at the same time. That kind of structure is a good platform for flavors of pear, exotic fruit, honey and almond. Try it with grilled shrimp in a cilantro pesto sauce.
column9: What's a red wine that's complex with layers of dark fruit and spices?,

column2: Enoport 2013 Tonel 22 Reserva Red (Douro)
column3: This is a wine that combines rich berry fruits and a layer of fine tannins. Juicy blackberry flavors are spiced with the wood aging and given a dark, solid texture from the structure. The wine is ready to drink, packed with fruit and spicy acidity.

column2: J. & F. Lurton 2005 Barco Negro Red (Douro)
column3: A richly ripe wine, full of tarry, dark tannins and black fruits. Despite its weight and density, it is well balanced, the dark flavors opening out with flavors of licorice, bitter chocolate and spicy wood.

column2: Dão Sul 2009 Cabriz Reserva Red (Dão)
column3: This complex, mature wine has plenty of red fruit flavors, but its main character displays concentrated, tannin and spice. Hints of leather and rich acidity add their notes to this dense, dusty wine. It is ready to drink although it will still mature until 2020.

column2: I Fabbri 2010 Riserva  (Chianti Classico)
column3: This wine starts off with aromas that recall charred wood and meat juices; soon these waft away to reveal black fruit and spice. The dense palate reveals a black cherry punctuated with black pepper, nutmeg and cinnamon along with a note of tobacco. It's well-balanced with brooding tannins and will develop more depth over the next few years.

column2: DFJ Vinhos 2010 Pedras do Monte Red (Lisboa)
column3: A dark colored red that is firmly tannic as well as ripe and fruity. The wine is spicy and earthy, redolent of dried fruits, like figs and red berries. With its solid texture, it can age; drink from 2015.
column9: Can you suggest a wine from Italy?,

column2: Feudo Antico 2008 Tullum Red (Abruzzo)
column3: This hearty red wine from central Italy would pair well with grilled meat or veal wrapped in sage leaves and sliced prosciutto ham. Loads of red berries are followed by notes of exotic spice, leather, tobacco and firm tannins. Drink in 3–5 more years.

column2: Torre Fornello 2011 Dorian Red (Emilia)
column3: Here's a great deal from central Italy. Dark with mature fruit and spice, this easy red wine would pair with pork or white meat. It offers a pleasing touch of rich sweetness on the close.

column2: Mocali 2010 Fossetti Red (Toscana)
column3: An 80-20 blend of Sangiovese and Canaiolo, this shows bright tones of cherry and blueberry, with a touch of bitter almond in the background. The wine's freshness would pair well with pasta with melted cheese.

column2: Lamoretti 2008 Vigna del Guasto Red (Emilia-Romagna)
column3: This thin and savory wine from the Colli di Parma appellation in central Italy offers bright spice and leather with subtle tones of cassis and dried prune. Pair it with homemade pasta or ravioli with ricotta cheese.

column2: Rocca delle Macìe 2009 Riserva di Fizzano  (Chianti Classico)
column3: Made in a very respectable Chianti Classico style, the wine delivers freshness, with tart berry notes and a bright, streamlined feel. Medallions of veal, grilled sausage or roast chicken would all pair nicely with this Sangiovese-based wine (with small percentages of Cabernet Sauvignon and Merlot).
column9: What would be a good wine for a quiet evening?,

column2: Fattoria Scopone 2006 Il Gregoriano Red (Sant'Antimo)
column3: Here's an easy Sangiovese-based wine (with a small percent of Petit Verdot for extra darkness and color) that would pair wonderfully with stay-home pizza or pasta. The wine offers bright berry nuances of cherry and raspberry and a touch of distant spice and smoke on the fade.

column2: Two Horns 2012 A Mean Red (California)
column3: Not too heavy or too rich, this medium-bodied wine has mellow spice and fruit flavors, good balance and a gentle texture. It will be perfect when you don't want to drink a blockbuster.

column2: Chime NV Schatz Family Vineyard Red (California)
column3: Easygoing and soft in texture, this medium-bodied red wine has fruity, jammy aromas and flavors, and blends in a little black pepper for interest.

column2: Barrel Road 2014 Artisan Blend Red (California)
column3: This light- to medium-bodied red wine doesn't take itself too seriously and will be versatile with food. The fruity, almost jammy and fresh aromas lead to dry, substantive flavors and a tempting, smooth texture.

column2: Cantina di Soave 2011 Rocca Alata  (Valpolicella Ripasso)
column3: Here's a simple but well made wine, with raspberry, cherry and red currant nuances punctuated by a hint of white pepper. It's soft and ready to drink young, with a nice freshness. This will go well with mushroom-stuffed ravioli.
column9: Can you recommend a white wine with a smooth, buttery texture?","

column2: Vignerons des Terres Secrètes 2008 Le Bouchon  (Mâcon-Villages)
column3: Beautifully textured wine, very creamy, the toast and butter from wood smoothing out the tight fruit texture. A fine, polished wine.

column2: Domaine Sangouard-Guyot 2010 Au Brûlé  (Saint-Véran)
column3: A simple, white fruited wine. Its texture is light, bright, the acidity coming from a touch of wood and apple and cream fruits. Easy drinking, ready to go.

column2: Patriarche Père et Fils 2013 Fourchaume Premier Cru  (Chablis)
column3: Soft and buttery, this wine is smooth and creamy with hints of citrus and a tangy backdrop. With a lightly toasty edge, the wine finishes more tightly than it starts. Drink now.

column2: Cave de Viré 2015 Grande Réserve du Président  (Mâcon-Villages)
column3: This soft wine has a gentle texture and smooth white fruits. It is fruity and lightly perfumed. With its crisp edge of acidity, is totally ready to drink.

column2: Monte del Frá 2005 Cà del Magro  (Custoza Superiore)
column3: One of the most attractive aspects of this fresh white blend is its structure: The wine is silky and smooth and seemingly weightless at the same time. That kind of structure is a good platform for flavors of pear, exotic fruit, honey and almond. Try it with grilled shrimp in a cilantro pesto sauce.
column9: I'm looking for a red wine that's both robust and elegant at the same time. Any recommendations?,

column2: Terra Silvestre 2010 Reserva Red (Tejo)
column3: Here is a solid, while also elegant, wine. It has rich berry and plum flavors, dark tannins and ample acidity. Already well integrated, these form a full, stylish wine that shows good potential. Drink this concentrated wine from 2017.

column2: Flora Springs 2014 Wild Boar Vineyard Cabernet Sauvignon (Napa Valley)
column3: Intensely robust and grippy in smoky oak, this is a well-built brawny red wine. Its flavors are textured and bold in cured meat, char and blackberry jam.

column2: Parras Vinhos 2008 Castelo do Sulco Colheita Red (Lisboa)
column3: Elegant, fresh wine, full of delicious red berry fruits, a fruit salad of red and black plums and a light touch of spice. Bright, juicy, ready to drink.

column2: Borges 2009 Lello Tinto Red (Douro)
column3: An attractive, bright, red-fruited wine, laced with intense acidity and a layer of tannins. The wine has great texture and some sweetness. A very drinkable red.

column2: Quinta da Alorna 2009 Portal da Aguia Red (Tejo)
column3: A full-bodied, rich wine that combines extra juiciness with delicious red-berry fruits. It is structured while being immediately attractive. It's a great wine to go with pasta dishes.
column9: I'd like a white wine, excluding Sauvignon Blanc.","

column2: Corvo 2009 Bianco White (Sicilia)
column3: This fresh, easy-going Sicilian white would go with fresh seafood or spicy Thai curry. The wine shows bright notes of peach and citrus with a touch of soft sweetness on the close.

column2: Tasca d'Almerita 2011 Leone d'Almerita White (Sicilia)
column3: This white blend is the quintessential seafood wine. It offers citrus, stone fruit, crushed mineral and pretty flower nuances.

column2: Corvo 2010 Fiore White (Sicilia)
column3: Here's an easy, no-fuss white wine to pair with rice salad or grilled vegetables. Citrus, almond blossom and stone fruit are capped by a slightly sweet feel in the mouth.

column2: Peter Zemmer 2011 Cortinie Bianco White (Vigneti delle Dolomiti)
column3: A blend of Chardonnay, Pinot Grigio, Gewürztraminer and Sauvignon, this aromatic white opens with a deeply-floral bouquet of rose, honeysuckle, salvia and white peach. Crisp acidity helps pull it together in the mouth.

column2: Viña Tabalí 2015 Pedregoso Gran Reserva Sauvignon Blanc (Limarí Valley)
column3: This Sauvignon Blanc looks only slightly more colorful than a glass of water. On the nose, it's crisp and green, while sharp acidity matched against a light body makes for a lean palate. Crisp salty citric flavors finish tight and linear.
column9: What's a full-bodied red wine?,

column2: Quinta da Alorna 2009 Portal da Aguia Red (Tejo)
column3: A full-bodied, rich wine that combines extra juiciness with delicious red-berry fruits. It is structured while being immediately attractive. It's a great wine to go with pasta dishes.

column2: Bowtie 2010 Showtime Red (California)
column3: This is a useful red wine for everyday drinking. Full-bodied and spicy, it offers plenty of berry, plum sauce and toasted wood flavors.

column2: Casey Flat Ranch 2011 Open Range Red (California)
column3: This full-bodied, focused and distinctive wine has a deep, dark color, aromas of black cherry and cocoa, and flavors that are ripe and lingering. It offers power and complexity.

column2: C. Cruz & Co 2007 Calheiros Cruz Red (Douro)
column3: A big, bold, ripe wine. It is full-bodied and peppery, full of blueberry fruit. Soft tannins finish with a light dry edge. Ready to drink.

column2: Real Companhia Velha 2008 Porca de Murça Reserva Red (Douro)
column3: Red fruits dominate a wine that is rich, full-bodied with a firm, tight structure. Round the firm texture there is a richer, ripe fruit character, dense and juicy. The wine can be aged, but it is ready to drink.
column9: Is there a wine that is not too acidic?,

column2: Maison Bouey 2014 La Vache Rosé (Bordeaux Rosé)
column3: This wine is so soft it is almost without taste. Only the acidity remains.

column2: Estandon 2013 Terres de Saint-Louis Rosé (Coteaux Varois en Provence)
column3: The wine is very crisp, but a tight, nervy and almost bitter acidity cuts through and is almost shocking. Maybe it will soften in a few months.

column2: De Mour 2009 Duc de Rochebois  (Bordeaux)
column3: A wine with light tannins and juicy red fruits. Though the acidity is prominent, it has a soft texture and attractive strawberry fruit flavors. Not for aging.

column2: Les Maîtres Vignerons de la Presqu'île de Saint-Tropez 2014 Domaine Aureillan Rosé (Côtes de Provence)
column3: This is a ripe, softly fruity wine that has acidity within a smooth texture. It is dry without being too tight or nervy. Citrus fruits dominate, giving a crisp aftertaste. Drink with food.
column7: Les Maîtres Vignerons de la Presqu'île de Saint-Tropez

column2: Château du Rouët 2014 Cuvée Réserve Tradition Rosé (Côtes de Provence)
column3: This simple, soft and fruity wine has attractive acidity as well as red currant fruit flavors. With its final tang of acidity, it's well placed as an apéritif.
column9: What's a dry white wine?,

column2: Collegiale des Domaines de Loire 2014 Les Bois de Vaux Sec  (Vouvray)
column3: This bone-dry wine offers flavors of white fruits. Its crisp acidity is tempered by a touch of honey and spicy almonds. Balanced and fruity, the wine is ready to drink.

column2: Domaine Pichot 2015 Coteau de la Biche Sec  (Vouvray)
column3: This dry wine shows hints of honey as well as pure sliced apple and white stone fruits. It is deliciously crisp, bright with acidity, almonds and a tangy texture. The wine is totally ready to drink in its fruity youth.

column2: Château de Fesles 2014 La Chapelle Vieilles Vignes Chenin Blanc (Anjou)
column3: This bone-dry, fresh wine is crisp with citrus and apple flavors. There are touches of wood aging that adds spice to the tangy acidity and touches of honey. Perfumed and bright at the end, the wine is ready to drink.

column2: Trabucco 2008 16 Marzo White (Falerno del Massico)
column3: This is an herbal, floral white wine with aromas that span from dried hay to pungent lemon blossom. It seems to give the best of itself on the bouquet, because in the mouth, this wine is fresh, compact and very easygoing.

column2: DFJ Vinhos 2016 Cara Viva Branco White (Lisboa)
column3: An off-dry pair with the rosé in this range, this is a soft white wine that is clean, fruity with attractive sweet pear and quince flavors. Drink now.
column9: I'm looking for a white wine that's light and refreshing with a hint of minerality.,

column2: Adalia 2015 Singan  (Soave)
column3: Here's a light-bodied casual wine that has subdued aromas suggesting white flower, orchard fruit and a hint of almond. You can find traces of the nose on the extremely simple diluted palate.

column2: Banear 2006 Mamàn White (Delle Venezie)
column3: A luminous Italian white wine offersing subdued tones of stone fruit, white mineral and honey. There's an aromatic component that is reminiscent of mint and the wine is clean and easy in the mouth with a vibrant, fresh finish.

column2: La Berrière 2016 Sur Lie  (Muscadet Côtes de Grandlieu)
column3: This is a fruity wine, gentle with its white fruits and citrus flavors. It has just a touch of minerality from the granite soil that brings out acidity and a tangy aftertaste. Drink this refreshing wine now.

column2: Tortoise Creek 2013 Le Charmel Sur Lie  (Muscadet Sèvre et Maine)
column3: This light and fruity wine is fresh with lemon and light minerality. It is ready to drink, with its bright acidity and pear and apple aftertaste.

column2: Tasca d'Almerita 2011 Leone d'Almerita White (Sicilia)
column3: This white blend is the quintessential seafood wine. It offers citrus, stone fruit, crushed mineral and pretty flower nuances.
column9: I'd like a dessert wine, excluding Riesling.","

column2: Hogue 1997 Genesis Schwartzman Vineyard Riesling (Yakima Valley)
column3: No oak here, thank you; just pure and delicious Riesling fruit with a hint of botrytis to add complexity to the apple-pear range of flavors. This dry-finished wine can hang with powerful chili-based dishes and is delightful as an aperitif.

column2: Lake Chelan 2010 Sweet Riesling (Lake Chelan)
column3: Not really sweet, and not entirely Riesling (the blend includes 13% Gewürztraminer and 10% Pinot Gris), this off-dry wine tastes like fresh squeezed apple juice, lightly sweetened.

column2: Alexandria Nicole 2008 Late Harvest Riesling (Horse Heaven Hills)
column3: Though the term late harvest would suggest a sweet, dessert wine, this is more on the off-dry side of Riesling, with juicy acids that cut the impression of sugar. Fragrant with scents and flavors of apricots, apple pie, honey and biscuit, it is expressive, nicely balanced and loaded with flavor.

column2: Hyatt 2008 Winter Harvest Riesling (Rattlesnake Hills)
column3: Succulent, dense and syrupy, this dessert Riesling brings a lush midpalate of honey, blossom, tea, candied citrus, butterscotch and more. It's loaded with flavor, just a little high-toned, and falls on the soft side for Washington dessert wines. But delicious? You bet!

column2: Sleight of Hand 2014 The Magician Evergreen Vineyard Riesling (Ancient Lakes)
column3: All Riesling, this aromatic wine conveys notes of jasmine, peach and pear. It drinks off dry, with spritzy soda water and stone-fruit flavors and mouthwatering acidity.
column9: Is there a wine that is not too tannic?,

column2: De Mour 2009 Duc de Rochebois  (Bordeaux)
column3: A wine with light tannins and juicy red fruits. Though the acidity is prominent, it has a soft texture and attractive strawberry fruit flavors. Not for aging.

column2: Beringer 2004 St. Helena Home Vineyard Cabernet Sauvignon (Napa Valley)
column3: There's a softness to this dry wine. It's forward and rich in currants and smoky oak, but could use greater acidity. The tannins also seem a little ungainly, although they could mellow out in a few years.

column2: Cheval Quancard 2012 Réserve  (Bordeaux)
column3: The wine feels light and very soft. There are some attractive red berry fruits, along with acidity and wood flavors, but the tannic structure is hardly there. It's an enjoyable, lightweight wine to drink now through 2016.

column2: Foundry Vineyards 2005 FV Red Wine Red (Walla Walla Valley (WA))
column3: This is soft and fruity, with a gentle mix of berries and spice. There isn't much depth evident, except for a somewhat astringent, bitter edge to the tannins.

column2: Cheval Quancard 2015 Chai de Bordes  (Bordeaux)
column3: The wine is soft with a fine touch of tannin and some stalkiness. It has black currants that are ripe while remaining crisp. The wine is easy, accessible and ready to drink.
column9: Can you suggest a white wine with a bright acidity and a touch of minerality?,

column2: Vincent 2011 JJ Bourgogne Blanc  (Bourgogne)
column3: Simple, bright white and citrus fruits give this wine a great lift from the start. There is a smooth, vanilla texture as well as a touch of minerality giving texture. The wine finishes with bright acidity.

column2: La Soufrandière 2012 Climat Les Quarts  (Pouilly-Vinzelles)
column3: The wine has good acidity, crisp green and white fruits, and a bright citrus element. Fresh and fruity, it's ready to drink, with a light mineral texture already well integrated.

column2: Henri de Villamont 2013 Grumes d'Or  (Pouilly-Fuissé)
column3: This attractive, steely wine has a good touch of minerality and hints of wood under the crisp lemon fruitiness. Textured with lively acidity and bright freshness, it is ready to drink.

column2: Esterlin NV Blanc de Blancs Brut Chardonnay (Champagne)
column3: A dry wine with mature white fruit and tight acidity, this wine will take time to coax out the rich, mineral character that hides within. It's touched with toast, but freshness and fruitiness dominate for a refreshing aftertaste.

column2: Yvon Mau 2009 Seigneurs de Bergerac Blanc White (Bergerac Sec)
column3: A bright, creamy wine with light acidity and flavors of green fruits, pears and a strong streak of grapefruit.
column9: Is there a wine that is not too sweet?,

column2: Arrow Creek 2010 Sweet Red Coastal Series Red (California)
column3: Sweet and simple, this soft wine has sugary berry and cola flavors.

column2: Casa Tiene Vista NV DeLuz Red (California)
column3: There's little going on in this wine beyond sugary sweetness and high alcohol. There's a hint of chocolate and blackberry.

column2: Two Horns 2012 A Mean Red (California)
column3: Not too heavy or too rich, this medium-bodied wine has mellow spice and fruit flavors, good balance and a gentle texture. It will be perfect when you don't want to drink a blockbuster.

column2: Gnarly Head 2015 Authentic Red (California)
column3: This lightly sweet and simple wine tastes straightforward, very fruity, soft in texture and light to medium in body.

column2: Fox Brook NV Sweet Red Table Wine Red (California)
column3: Like the label says, this red wine is sweet. It has raspberry and cherry flavors, with a pretty dusting of cinnamon spice. If sweet is your thing, drink up. The price is right.
column9: Can you recommend a white wine that's creamy with a hint of vanilla or oak?,

column2: Teruzzi & Puthod 2006 Terre di Tufi White (Toscana)
column3: This popular white wine from Tuscany is aged three months in oak for extra softness and creaminess. Aromas include honey, peach and slightly roasted almond. Pair this pretty wine with spicy Indian or Thai curries.

column2: Bouchaine 2012 Bouche d'Or Chardonnay (Carneros)
column3: A beautiful wine to pair with desserts based on white fruits or simple but delicious vanilla sponge cake. Made from late-harvested Chardonnay, it's very sweet in apricots, lemons, vanilla and buttered toast, with a brisk edge of acidity for balance.

column2: Astoria 2006 Crevada White (Colli di Conegliano)
column3: Here is a friendly, oak-aged blend with aromas of peach, vanilla, exotic fruit and butterscotch. The wine is luminous and bright and its soft, silky texture would work nicely with simple chicken or pan-fried fish in butter sauce.

column2: Tua Rita 2007 Lodano White (Toscana)
column3: This is a creamy and opulent oak-aged white blend from Tuscany (with equal parts Traminer, Riesling and Chardonnay) that opens with a luminous golden color and delicious aromas of exotic fruit, pineapple, yellow rose and melted butter. The wine is rich and dense with enormous intensity on the finish. Pair it with lobster, white meat or saffron risotto.

column2: Cantina Santadi 2008 Villa di Chiesa  (Valli di Porto Pino)
column3: This oak-heavy blend of Chardonnay and indigenous Sicilian grapes opens with luscious tones of toasted almond, apricot and candied lemon. There's a spicy vanilla note on the close, and the wine will appeal to those who appreciate an oaky Italian white.
column9: I'd like a red wine, excluding Chardonnay.","

column2: Magnificent Wine Company 2007 House Wine Red (Columbia Valley (WA))
column3: An all-purpose red wine, blending seven different grapes into a fruit bowl of forward berry flavors. Nothing challenging here, but the fruit is tasty and it might be compared to a nice Beaujolais—chill it and drink it outdoors on a hot summer day.

column2: Red Theory 2012 Winemaker's Red (Columbia Valley (WA))
column3: A straightforward wine with light notes of red and blue berries along with oak accents.

column2: Château de Saint-Martin 2014 Cuvée Grande Réserve Rosé (Côtes de Provence)
column3: This is a pale-colored wine, very fruity and crisp with an impressively refreshing quality. A touch of pepper gives interest to this dry, easy-drinking wine.

column2: Tagaris 2007 Frank Chiullino Chef Blend Red Red (Columbia Valley (WA))
column3: This red wine, named for the chef at the winery restaurant, is fruity and high-toned, with lots of cherry and berry flavor. All neutral oak, soft tannins, ready to drink.

column2: Convergence Zone 2011 Squall Line Red (Red Mountain)
column3: This soft red wine discloses pomegranate fruit and a liberal amount of Mediterranean herbs. It's light and easy-sipping, and should be consumed while young.
column9: Can you suggest a red wine with a good balance between fruitiness and acidity?,

column2: Château les Valentines 2012 La Caprice de Clémentine Rosé (Côtes de Provence)
column3: A deliciously crisp wine, the acidity streaking through the red berry fruits leaving a refreshing character that balances the touch of spice. Fresh, fruity and ready to drink.

column2: Domaine Parigot 2013 Les Peuillets Premier Cru  (Savigny-lès-Beaune)
column3: This ripe and soft wine has a great balance between the rich red berry fruits, bright cherries and acidity. The structure is full, generous and gives the wine a comfortable feel. Acidity at the end lends a fresher aspect. Drink from 2017.

column2: Casa Agricola Santos Jorge 2014 Toutalga Red (Alentejano)
column3: This is a young, fruity wine with fine acidity and plenty of red-fruit flavors. Light spice, generous tannins and a hint of wood all contribute to a balanced wine that is ready to drink.

column2: Ruhlmann NV Harmonie Rosé Pinot Noir (Crémant d'Alsace)
column3: In this soft, ripe wine, red fruits are balanced by acidity, while the gentle texture marries well with the light mousse. It's immediately attractive with its fresh aftertaste.

column2: Dão Sul 2009 Cortello Tinto Red (Lisboa)
column3: Fruity red berry-flavored wine, with attractive light tannins, plenty of acidity and an earthy edge. There's a touch of pepper, the finish showing fine acidity.
column9: Can you suggest a red wine that's both spicy and full-bodied?,

column2: Bowtie 2010 Showtime Red (California)
column3: This is a useful red wine for everyday drinking. Full-bodied and spicy, it offers plenty of berry, plum sauce and toasted wood flavors.

column2: Rare NV 4 Grape Blend Red (California)
column3: Here's a good, robust red wine. It's made in a country-style, with tobacco, cherry and spice flavors and a jagged mouthfeel. Drink it with tacos and burgers.

column2: Elyse 2010 C'Est Si Bon Red (California)
column3: Here is a hearty, full-bodied and dry red blend with a vivid black cherry character and spicy accents like black pepper and fennel. Firm and quite tannic, it will pair nicely with rich meat or cheese dishes that need a little bite in the wine to balance them.

column2: DFJ Vinhos 2008 Casa do Lago Red (Lisboa)
column3: Bright red-fruited wine, its acidity well blended into the soft, full fruit. The wine has spice, toast, wild herbs.

column2: Wines & Winemakers 2011 Companhia das Lezírias Catapereiro Red (Tejo)
column3: This is a spicy wine that is full of juicy red-berry fruit notes. It is soft and gentle, with a core of dry tannins that gives the wine structure. Young and fruity, it is ready to drink, but will also age. Drink until 2018.
column9: I'm curious about trying a red wine with smoky or toasty flavors. Any suggestions?,

column2: Dunham 2009 Trutina Red (Columbia Valley (WA))
column3: A blend of 60% Cabernet Sauvignon and four other grapes, this toasty red will please anyone who likes a red wine with satiny, milk chocolate goodness. The fruit and mouth-coating barrel flavors are fine, though there is just a hint of a green edge to the tannins.

column2: Hey Mambo 2013 Sultry Red (California)
column3: This lightly sweet wine has an intense oaky, peppery, smoky aroma and the flavors come out the same way. The beefy, liquid-smoke character should match ribs in barbecue sauce.

column2: Donkey & Goat 2015 The Gallivanter Red (California)
column3: This wine is like an adventurous trek through the mountains, with wild, smoky, forest aromas, gamy, black-peppery flavors and a rugged texture that's inviting. Flavor nuances come out with each sip, yielding blackberry, blueberry and grilled steak.

column2: Tassi 2004 Aquabona Red (Toscana)
column3: This bold, spicy wine will appeal to those who love modern reds with thick concentration and lingering oak-driven flavors. Black cherry, prune and ripe blueberry do come into view, but the protagonist here is the oak. The wine has chewy tannins, good length on the finish and would pair with grilled meats or aged cheeses.

column2: Rare NV 4 Grape Blend Red (California)
column3: Here's a good, robust red wine. It's made in a country-style, with tobacco, cherry and spice flavors and a jagged mouthfeel. Drink it with tacos and burgers.
column9: What would be a good wine for a celebration?,

column2: Bellini 2008 VYD Red (Toscana)
column3: This is a very informal and easygoing red table wine that would taste great with pizza. It opens with a bright ruby color and shows aromas of cherry, raspberry and toasted almond.

column2: Risata NV Il Rosso Red (Italy)
column3: This sweet, fizzy red would pair well with sweet almond cookies or spicy banana bread. It's an easy but cheerful wine to sip at the end of a long, satisfying meal.

column2: Castello di Montegiove 2010 Gatto Gatto  (Orvieto)
column3: Sometimes you need a light and refreshing red wine to serve with burgers or franks. This informal wine from Umbria shows an easy bouquet that is characterized by black fruit, bacon and cured meat.

column2: Feudo Antico 2008 Tullum Red (Abruzzo)
column3: This hearty red wine from central Italy would pair well with grilled meat or veal wrapped in sage leaves and sliced prosciutto ham. Loads of red berries are followed by notes of exotic spice, leather, tobacco and firm tannins. Drink in 3–5 more years.

column2: Saladini Pilastri 2010 Piediprato  (Rosso Piceno)
column3: Perfect for meat dishes or grilled lamb chops, this is a lush and soft red wine that offers a cheerful and informal personality. Ripe cherry, prune and light spice make for an easy-drinking proposition.
column9: Are there any red wines with a hint of chocolate or cocoa notes?,

column2: Fuligni 2005 S.J. (San Jacopo) Red (Toscana)
column3: This modern red from the Montalcino area of Tuscany exhibits amazing chocolate-like intensity with dark shades of espresso bean, black cherry, vanilla, incense and strawberry cola. It has so much cherry in the mouth it recalls cherry liqueur or cherry-chocolate cake.

column2: Walla Walla Vintners 2013 Bello Rosso Red (Columbia Valley (WA))
