column3: This wine is equal parts Sangiovese and Cabernet Sauvignon. Cabernet takes the lead on the aromas, with notes of dark cherry and dried herbs along with hints of toast, coffee and cocoa. The elegant milk chocolate and cherry flavors are brightened by the Sangiovese's tart acidity.

column2: O•S Winery 2006 Red Wine Red (Washington)
column3: This inexpensive red wine has muscle and depth. It's chocolaty, rich and loaded with ripe, supple fruits and smooth caramel. There is plenty of coffee flavor, a sweet and broad mid-palate, and a simple but satisfying finish.

column2: Hightower 2005 Red Mountain Red Red (Red Mountain)
column3: This well-crafted red wine is supple and smooth. It opens with scents of violets and berries, fills in with round, lush berry and cherry fruit flavors, then applies a wash of milk chocolate to the tannins.

column2: Hourglass 2012 Blueline Vineyard Cabernet Sauvignon (Napa Valley)
column3: An inky-deep color with a dark red rim hints at the concentration. Enticing aromas from the spice rack, milk chocolate and vanilla lead to meltingly rich fruit and cocoa flavors that are deep and focused. At first sip it's almost sweet with ripe black cherry and black currant notes, but the vivid acidity and layer of fine tannins keep it dry and balanced. It will be best after 2020.
column9: Can you recommend a red wine with a balanced acidity and red fruit flavors?,

column2: Casa Agricola Santos Jorge 2014 Toutalga Red (Alentejano)
column3: This is a young, fruity wine with fine acidity and plenty of red-fruit flavors. Light spice, generous tannins and a hint of wood all contribute to a balanced wine that is ready to drink.

column2: Barton & Guestier 2011 Bistro Pinot Noir (Ile de Beauté)
column3: Soft and fruity with some sweetness, this red-fruit-flavored wine is rounded and warm, crispened by acidity.

column2: Symington Family Estates 2012 Altano Red (Douro)
column3: This accessible, red-fruited wine has layers of fresh acidity, soft tannins and an immediate smoothness, with subtle hints of minerality. Lively acidity and fresh fruit flavors are left to linger on the finish.

column2: Fiuza 2016 Oceanus Red (Tejo)
column3: This is a simple, fruity wine, balanced and with red-berry fruits. It has soft tannins and a line of attractive acidity, and is ready to drink.

column2: J. Portugal Ramos 2015 Vila Santa Loios Tinto Red (Alentejano)
column3: This is a fruity wine with crisp red fruits and acidity that are balanced by gentle tannins. With its warm feel, it is an easy wine that is ready to drink.
column9: I prefer white wines that are aromatic with floral or honeysuckle notes. Any suggestions?,

column2: Trabucco 2008 16 Marzo White (Falerno del Massico)
column3: This is an herbal, floral white wine with aromas that span from dried hay to pungent lemon blossom. It seems to give the best of itself on the bouquet, because in the mouth, this wine is fresh, compact and very easygoing.

column2: Tenute Soletta 2010 Kyanos White (Isola dei Nuraghi)
column3: This blended white wine from Sardinia opens with fragrant tones of soapy spring flower, honeysuckle and peach blossom. There are touches of caramel and butterscotch as well.

column2: Cascata 2006 Cascade Riesling (Finger Lakes)
column3: This wine offers aromas of white flowers, spice and citrus. On the palate are easygoing flavors of white fruit, flowers and minerally spice. A simply good white wine with a feminine touch.

column2: Monte del Frá 2005 Cà del Magro  (Custoza Superiore)
column3: One of the most attractive aspects of this fresh white blend is its structure: The wine is silky and smooth and seemingly weightless at the same time. That kind of structure is a good platform for flavors of pear, exotic fruit, honey and almond. Try it with grilled shrimp in a cilantro pesto sauce.

column2: Gancia NV Grand Reale White (Piedmont)
column3: Here is a sweet and fragrant dessert wine with aromas of white flower, honey and stone fruit accented by a slightly drying mineral characteristic. Firm, tonic effervescence keeps the palate refreshed even when paired with whipped cream or creamy fruit desserts.
column9: Could you suggest a white wine with a creamy texture and tropical fruit notes?,

column2: J. Portugal Ramos 2012 Marquês de Borba Branco White (Alentejo)
column3: A smooth, creamy textured wine that has both citrus and richer tropical fruits. Pineapple and lemon mingle with a more zesty acidity to give a fruity wine that could age for a few months.

column2: Monte del Frá 2005 Cà del Magro  (Custoza Superiore)
column3: One of the most attractive aspects of this fresh white blend is its structure: The wine is silky and smooth and seemingly weightless at the same time. That kind of structure is a good platform for flavors of pear, exotic fruit, honey and almond. Try it with grilled shrimp in a cilantro pesto sauce.

column2: Quinta do Pinto 2008 Branco Reserva White (Lisboa)
column3: Warm, rich wine with tropical flavors of mango, peach and with a ripe feel. It has weight, although the fruit does hint at crispness. There is a toast and nuts character that broadens out the interest.

column2: Salviano 2012 Salviano  (Orvieto Classico)
column3: Here's a delightful and straightforward wine that opens with a delicate fragrance of white spring flowers. The palate offers notes of tropical fruit, lemon zest and a hint of clove. It has a clean, quenching finish.

column2: Herdade do Esporão 2008 Esporão Private Selection White (Alentejo)
column3: A ripe, creamy Chardonnay-like wine, the tropical orange and lychee fruits pointed up with new French wood. The fresh lime acidity cuts through the richness like a knife. This is a complex wine that would profit from a year's aging.
column9: Can you suggest a white wine that's crisp and has a hint of grassiness or herbaceousness?,

column2: Château Lamothe-Vincent 2006 Héritage  (Bordeaux Blanc)
column3: This grassy, very herbaceous wine is all crisp green fruits. Touched by a creamy texture under a layer of freshness, it shows some good weight and structure. There is light wood that rounds it all out.

column2: Maycas del Limari 2007 Reserva Especial Sauvignon Blanc (Limarí Valley)
column3: Grassy and green-smelling, with hints of asparagus, green tobacco and sea air. This is true cool-climate white wine, and it shows its proximity to the ocean via aromas of green bean, asparagus and citrus. It's lean as can be, and tight as a drum. It's a terroir wine that has good freshness but could benefit from slightly more amplified fruit.

column2: Château Puy-Servain 2007 Marjolaine  (Montravel)
column3: Full, firm white wine that gives good green fruit and pear flavors, lifted with spice from wood. The wine is round, while still retaining crispness from grassy acidity, and offers a good depth of plum skin structure and flavor.

column2: Il Roncal 2006 Pinot Grigio Pinot Grigio (Colli Orientali del Friuli)
column3: There's a fragrant grassy or herbal quality that is backed by copious tones of mature fruit, melon and grapefruit. This is a distinctive, personality-driven wine with a creamy, full texture that would pair with shellfish or white meat.

column2: Les Vignerons Réunis de Monségur 2015 Château Tuilerie Pagès  (Entre-Deux-Mers)
column3: This is a crisp herbal wine, bright with acidity and marked with lemon and grapefruit tastes. It is light and bright with a mineral edge that gives it a fine texture. Drink now.
column9: What's a good white wine with a bright acidity and stone fruit flavors?,

column2: Herdade Grande 2007 Condado das Vinhas White (Alentejano)
column3: A rounded, soft wine, hinting at some minerality, with a white stone fruit flavor, crisply citrus. The wine only gradually shows more fruit flavor, the roundness then freshened up with acidity. There is a good final balance.

column2: Vincent 2011 JJ Bourgogne Blanc  (Bourgogne)
column3: Simple, bright white and citrus fruits give this wine a great lift from the start. There is a smooth, vanilla texture as well as a touch of minerality giving texture. The wine finishes with bright acidity.

column2: Adega Cooperativa do Cartaxo 2010 Xairel Branco White (Tejo)
column3: Fresh, apple-flavored wine, full of white fruits and a tangy, bright acidity. The wine is deliciously fresh, with stone fruit acidity on the finish.

column2: Domaine Sangouard-Guyot 2010 Au Brûlé  (Saint-Véran)
column3: A simple, white fruited wine. Its texture is light, bright, the acidity coming from a touch of wood and apple and cream fruits. Easy drinking, ready to go.

column2: Morey-Blanc 2007 Charmes Premier Cru  (Meursault)
column3: With wood and white stone fruit in fine balance, this is a ripe, full wine, the acidity lighting up the ripe flavor. The wine has a broad character, ready for drinking in a year.
column9: Recommend a wine with hints of berry.,

column2: Speri 2008 La Roverina  (Valpolicella)
column3: Bright and correct with clean berry flavors, this is a perfect red wine to pair with meat appetizers or pâtè. It delivers a thin, watery feel with loads of crisp berry freshness in the mouth.

column2: Tommasi 2010 Vigneto Rafaèl  (Valpolicella Classico Superiore)
column3: This bright wine offers delicate fruit notes of wild berry and white cherry, backed by hints of black pepper and cola. Easy on the palate, it shows a fresh point of acidity on the finish.

column2: Batzella 2009 Digià  (Bolgheri)
column3: The wine is redolent of bright blueberry and cherry with a tonic, youthful berry feel in the mouth. This easy blend of Cabernet Sauvignon (60%), Syrah and Cabernet Franc would make the perfect companion to pizza or pasta.

column2: Cantina di Soave 2011 Rocca Alata  (Valpolicella Ripasso)
column3: Here's a simple but well made wine, with raspberry, cherry and red currant nuances punctuated by a hint of white pepper. It's soft and ready to drink young, with a nice freshness. This will go well with mushroom-stuffed ravioli.

column2: Guado al Melo 2013 Bacco in Toscana Red (Toscana)
column3: Bright berry and dark spice aromas waft out of the glass. A blend of Sangiovese and Syrah, the easy-drinking palate delivers blackberries, crushed raspberries and ground pepper alongside polished tannins. Drink soon.
column9: Is there a wine that is not too sweet?,

column2: Arrow Creek 2010 Sweet Red Coastal Series Red (California)
column3: Sweet and simple, this soft wine has sugary berry and cola flavors.

column2: Casa Tiene Vista NV DeLuz Red (California)
column3: There's little going on in this wine beyond sugary sweetness and high alcohol. There's a hint of chocolate and blackberry.

column2: Two Horns 2012 A Mean Red (California)
column3: Not too heavy or too rich, this medium-bodied wine has mellow spice and fruit flavors, good balance and a gentle texture. It will be perfect when you don't want to drink a blockbuster.

column2: Gnarly Head 2015 Authentic Red (California)
column3: This lightly sweet and simple wine tastes straightforward, very fruity, soft in texture and light to medium in body.

column2: Fox Brook NV Sweet Red Table Wine Red (California)
column3: Like the label says, this red wine is sweet. It has raspberry and cherry flavors, with a pretty dusting of cinnamon spice. If sweet is your thing, drink up. The price is right.
column9: Recommend a wine with hints of oak.,

column2: Red Theory 2012 Winemaker's Red (Columbia Valley (WA))
column3: A straightforward wine with light notes of red and blue berries along with oak accents.

column2: Argiano 2010 Solengo Red (Toscana)
column3: This oak-dominated wine recalls the ubiquitous wood-driven Tuscan offerings from the late 1990s and early 2000s. A blend of Cabernet, Petit Verdot, Merlot and Syrah, it delivers hardcore oak, wood chips, vanilla, chocolate and espresso sensations, with black currant and blackberry lying low in the foreground.

column2: Tassi 2004 Aquabona Red (Toscana)
column3: This bold, spicy wine will appeal to those who love modern reds with thick concentration and lingering oak-driven flavors. Black cherry, prune and ripe blueberry do come into view, but the protagonist here is the oak. The wine has chewy tannins, good length on the finish and would pair with grilled meats or aged cheeses.

column2: Ioppa 2011 Balsina  (Ghemme)
column3: This shows more oak-driven sensations than you would expect from a wine aged in large casks, opening with aromas of oak, coconut, vanilla and an underpinning of ripe dark berry. The firm palate offers dried black cherry, espresso, chopped sage and licorice alongside rather austere, close-grained tannins.

column2: Tenuta I Greppi 2009 Greppicaia  (Bolgheri Superiore)
column3: This shows bold oak tones of toast and spice that will unwind with 3–5 more years of bottle age. Beyond the notes of cinnamon and tobacco, this blend of Merlot, Cabernet Sauvignon and Cabernet Franc shows austerity and complexity, with touches of dark plum and tangy barbecue sauce. Give it a few more years.
column9: I'd like a rose wine, excluding Pinot Noir.","

column2: WesMar 2013 Salzgeber Vineyard Pinot Noir (Russian River Valley)
column3: Floral like a bouquet of roses, this pretty wine is lined in a tight structure of sinewy earthiness. Orange, cranberry and rhubarb define a crisp, tart profile, while oak makes a sneak, welcome appearance that doesn't overstay its welcome.

column2: Acrobat 2015 Rosé of Pinot Noir (Willamette Valley)
column3: Production has increased six-fold in this vintage, good news for rosé lovers. Dry and flavorful, this all-Pinot wine deftly incorporates floral (rose petals), botanical (gin-like), citrus (orange peel) and peach-skin components. It's fresh and penetrating.

column2: Balletto 2015 Cider Ridge Vineyard Pinot Noir (Russian River Valley)
column3: A softly unfussy wine with moderate acidity, this is rounded and light-bodied, with rose petal and red cherry aromas. The oak is subtle and supportive.

column2: Cartograph 2012 Rosé of Pinot Noir (Russian River Valley)
column3: This wine does a good job of transforming ripe Pinot grapes, with all their raspberry and cherry fruit, into a rosé that's ethereal and delicate. The wine is dry and the alcohol level is moderate, making it delicate and crisp in the mouth.

column2: JCB 2011 No. 11 Pinot Noir (Sonoma Coast)
column3: Light in color and lilting floral aromas of rose, this is an inviting cool-climate Pinot Noir swirling in equal parts strawberry and spice, subtle and sophisticated.
column9: What red wines would you suggest for someone who enjoys a well-integrated oak influence?,

column2: Tassi 2004 Aquabona Red (Toscana)
column3: This bold, spicy wine will appeal to those who love modern reds with thick concentration and lingering oak-driven flavors. Black cherry, prune and ripe blueberry do come into view, but the protagonist here is the oak. The wine has chewy tannins, good length on the finish and would pair with grilled meats or aged cheeses.

column2: Leone de Castris 2005 Riserva Red (Salice Salentino)
column3: This is an oak-heavy red wine from Southern Italy that is embellished by aromas of vanilla, toast and spice that sit heavy over a rich core of ripe fruit. The wine is firm and streamlined in the mouth and offers a hint of sour cherry on the close. This vintage represents a huge jump forward in quality compared to 2004.

column2: Argiano 2010 Solengo Red (Toscana)
column3: This oak-dominated wine recalls the ubiquitous wood-driven Tuscan offerings from the late 1990s and early 2000s. A blend of Cabernet, Petit Verdot, Merlot and Syrah, it delivers hardcore oak, wood chips, vanilla, chocolate and espresso sensations, with black currant and blackberry lying low in the foreground.

column2: Donatella Cinelli Colombini 2004 Fattoria del Colle Cenerentola Red (Orcia)
column3: This red has a wide and broad personality that encompasses aromas of black fruit, leather and tobacco. There's less fresh fruit here: the wine definitely focuses on oak-driven tones, but it is lively enough to pair with roasted meat or dishes that require a touch of juicy succulence.

column2: Red Theory 2012 Winemaker's Red (Columbia Valley (WA))
column3: A straightforward wine with light notes of red and blue berries along with oak accents.
column9: I prefer white wines with a hint of honey or floral sweetness. Any recommendations?,

column2: Gancia NV Grand Reale White (Piedmont)
column3: Here is a sweet and fragrant dessert wine with aromas of white flower, honey and stone fruit accented by a slightly drying mineral characteristic. Firm, tonic effervescence keeps the palate refreshed even when paired with whipped cream or creamy fruit desserts.

column2: Bigi 2009 Amabile  (Orvieto Classico)
column3: Here's a sweet white wine (the term Amabile refers to the high sugar content) that opens with compelling notes of honey, acacia flower, peach and yellow candy. It's hard to imagine what to pair it with: It could either go with fruit salad or salty crackers with cheese.

column2: Trabucco 2008 16 Marzo White (Falerno del Massico)
column3: This is an herbal, floral white wine with aromas that span from dried hay to pungent lemon blossom. It seems to give the best of itself on the bouquet, because in the mouth, this wine is fresh, compact and very easygoing.

column2: Boeckel 2013 Vendanges Tardives Gewurztraminer (Alsace)
column3: Light and fruity, this wine has as much perfumed fruit as honeyed sweetness. It's a delicate wine, hinting at rosewater and spice. A smooth texture and lemon juice balance the honey at the end.

column2: Tenute Soletta 2010 Kyanos White (Isola dei Nuraghi)
column3: This blended white wine from Sardinia opens with fragrant tones of soapy spring flower, honeysuckle and peach blossom. There are touches of caramel and butterscotch as well.
column9: I'm looking for a white wine that's vibrant and citrusy with a crisp finish.,

column2: Quinta do Casal Branco 2013 Terra de Lobos Branco White (Tejo)
column3: This crisp and fresh wine suggests citrus and green apple fruits. It is light, fragrant and ready to drink with its bright final acidity.

column2: Adega Cooperativa de Borba 2016 Adega de Borba Branco White (Alentejo)
column3: Crisp, bright and fruity, this is a refreshing and ripe wine. With attractive citrus acidity and a bright aftertaste, the wine is ready to drink.

column2: Quinta da Foz 2014 Vinha da Foz Branco White (Douro)
column3: A fresh, citrus-flavored wine that is all about fruitiness. It is light, bright and tangy with orange and lemon zest. It is floral, crisp and ready to drink.

column2: Quinta dos Roques 2008 Quinta do Correio White (Dão)
column3: A crisp, fresh white wine, with clean acidity and a forward, easy lemon and melon character, with a hint of honey from the Malvasia Fina grapes in the blend.

column2: Adega Cooperativa de Borba 2015 Monte Claros Colheita Branco White (Alentejo)
column3: A light, citrus dominated wine, this is fresh and fruity. It has an attractive, clean palate, simple fruits and crisp acidity. The wine is ready to drink.
column9: Is there a light-bodied white wine that pairs well with seafood?,

column2: Tasca d'Almerita 2011 Leone d'Almerita White (Sicilia)
column3: This white blend is the quintessential seafood wine. It offers citrus, stone fruit, crushed mineral and pretty flower nuances.

column2: Le Due Terre 2009 Sacrisassi Bianco White (Colli Orientali del Friuli)
column3: A gorgeous blend of Friulano and Ribolla Gialla, this dense and rich white would pair with crab or lobster. It opens with creamy tones of stone fruit and citrus mousse, followed by slight touches of spice and vanilla.

column2: Masi 2009 Masianco White (Delle Venezie)
column3: Pinot Grigio and Verduzzo are blended to shape a fresh and luminous white wine that would pair with seafood or light chicken dishes. The wine is clean and sharp on the palate with zesty acidity on the close.

column2: Monte del Frá 2005 Cà del Magro  (Custoza Superiore)
column3: One of the most attractive aspects of this fresh white blend is its structure: The wine is silky and smooth and seemingly weightless at the same time. That kind of structure is a good platform for flavors of pear, exotic fruit, honey and almond. Try it with grilled shrimp in a cilantro pesto sauce.

column2: Corvo 2009 Bianco White (Sicilia)
column3: This fresh, easy-going Sicilian white would go with fresh seafood or spicy Thai curry. The wine shows bright notes of peach and citrus with a touch of soft sweetness on the close.
column9: What's a bold white wine?,

column2: Maison Champy 2006 Les Grands Charrons  (Meursault)
column3: A big, fat, spicy wine flavored with white fruits and laced with crisp acidity. It is full and opulent, but not extravagantly so, the acidity cutting through richness, leaving yellow fruits and some toast.

column2: Larmandier-Bernier NV Latitude Extra Brut Chardonnay (Champagne)
column3: Although it's not indicated on the label, this is a Blanc de Blancs from Chardonnay. It is warm and ripe, with a soft texture allied to fresh acidity. Orange and lemon zest give a great lift to this rounded wine.

column2: Trabucco 2008 16 Marzo White (Falerno del Massico)
column3: This is an herbal, floral white wine with aromas that span from dried hay to pungent lemon blossom. It seems to give the best of itself on the bouquet, because in the mouth, this wine is fresh, compact and very easygoing.

column2: Xavier Monnot 2006 Les Chevalières  (Meursault)
column3: A powerfully rich wine that brings in delicious white and yellow fruit flavors. It is unctuous, rounded, made richer with toast then given a boost by a streak of fresh citrus acidity. Good, plump white Burgundy.

column2: Domaine Sangouard-Guyot 2010 Au Brûlé  (Saint-Véran)
column3: A simple, white fruited wine. Its texture is light, bright, the acidity coming from a touch of wood and apple and cream fruits. Easy drinking, ready to go.
column9: Are there any white wines with a distinctive mineral or chalky quality?,

column2: Domaine Faiveley 2011 Clos Rochette  (Mercurey)
column3: The chalky soil yields a crisp, textured wine with yellow fruits to round it out. There is a steely edge and just a touch of wood, while the aftertaste is packed with acidity.

column2: Pol Roger 2000 Blanc de Blancs Brut Chardonnay (Champagne)
column3: Bringing out all the minerality of the chalk soils, this rounded wine is also packed with rich fruits. The wine is just approaching its peak, showing wonderful lemon and white stone fruits.

column2: Bret Brothers 2010 Climat en Combe  (Saint-Véran)
column3: This is a rich, fruity wine that has a definite minerally character. The chalky texture is laced with lemon and apricot flavors, leading to a crisp, tight finish.

column2: Agrapart & Fils 2000 Minéral Extra Brut Chardonnay (Champagne)
column3: The fact that this wine comes from the chalkiest of soils and is bone dry gives it considerable austerity. It is definitely mineral in taste and texture, with a touch of salt and grapefruit flavors;  very structured and tight. It needs to age.

column2: Lombard et Cie NV Brut Nature Cramant Blanc de Blancs Grand Cru Chardonnay (Champagne)
column3: One of a pair of blanc de blancs from grand cru vineyards, this is a chalky, flinty-textured wine. It is crisp and tight, still young and needing to age. It offers an appealing aromatic character, shot through with citrus and green-fruit acidity. Drink this bottling (disgorged January 2016) from 2018.
column9: Can you suggest a white wine with a crisp acidity and citrus notes?,

column2: Quinta do Casal Branco 2013 Terra de Lobos Branco White (Tejo)
column3: This crisp and fresh wine suggests citrus and green apple fruits. It is light, fragrant and ready to drink with its bright final acidity.

column2: Quinta dos Roques 2008 Quinta do Correio White (Dão)
column3: A crisp, fresh white wine, with clean acidity and a forward, easy lemon and melon character, with a hint of honey from the Malvasia Fina grapes in the blend.

column2: Cantine Rallo 2015 Al Qasar White (Sicilia)
column3: Here's a straightforward, crisp white that opens with aromas of orange blossom and citrus. The bright palate shows apricot, lime and lemon zest alongside refreshing acidity.

column2: Quinta dos Murças 2016 Assobio Branco White (Douro)
column3: This is a deliciously creamy wine with light white fruits and refreshing acidity. With its cool texture and minerality, it is crisp and zesty and ready to drink.

column2: Adega Cooperativa de Borba 2016 Adega de Borba Branco White (Alentejo)
column3: Crisp, bright and fruity, this is a refreshing and ripe wine. With attractive citrus acidity and a bright aftertaste, the wine is ready to drink.
column9: What red wines would you suggest for someone who enjoys a long, lingering finish?","

column2: Les Vins de Vienne 2009 Les Pimpignoles  (Gigondas)
column3: This wine has plenty to offer, from brightly fruity and peppery aromas to flavors of cherry, leather amd spice. The tannins are silky in texture, and the lengthy finish develops hints of cocoa and clove.

column2: Domaine de Poulvarel 2009 Les Grès Red (Costières de Nîmes)
column3: This medium-bodied wine combines grilled cherries with meaty, savory notes. It's not the biggest, baddest or boldest, but it is nicely harmonious and fruit-forward, with a long, mouthwatering finish. Drink it over the next year or two.

column2: Freeman 2014 Gloria Estate Pinot Noir (Russian River Valley)
column3: It's difficult to match the pure, expressive fruit and focus of this medium- to full-bodied, concentrated and complex wine. Substantial, enticing aromas of red and black cherry with a touch of butter lead to cherry, rhubarb, forest floor and mint notes on the palate. The mouthfeel is full but lively, and the finish lingers nicely. Best after 2022.

column2: Stemmler 2010 Nugent Vineyard Pinot Noir (Russian River Valley)
column3: Concentrated and elusively complex in cherry, red currant and sandalwood flavors, with a hint of red tomato and bloody red meat that testifies to the cool vintage. It's a big, dense wine, but also quite tannic, and a little high in alcohol, giving it a full body. A bit ungainly now, but impressive nonetheless for sheer power. Give it six years in the cellar.

column2: Henri Milan 2006 Les Clos Red (Les Baux de Provence)
column3: Big, spicy wine with its dark tannins and black fruit. Dark chocolate flavors go with the fruit, a rich and complex array of flavors that bring in herbs and spices as well as wood. Age for another 1–2 years.
column9: Looking for a wine that is estate-bottled.,

column2: Willamette Valley Vineyards 2014 Estate Pinot Noir (Willamette Valley)
column3: The Estate bottling, at least at the moment, is a light and delicate wine, with more than a hint of beetroot and stem. The cherry fruit is pleasant and a bit thin, but the wine has some complexity, which shows in the residual flavors of orange peel.

column2: Lenné Estate 2014 Estate Pinot Noir
column3: This barrel selection is difficult to spot, because the word “estate” is just very lightly imprinted under the name Lenné. It's clearly a bigger juicier more tannic wine than its excellent sibling, with deep flavors of raspberry fruit, highlights of white pepper, and acids that push the flavors down through the palate.

column2: Willamette Valley Vineyards 2006 Estate Vineyard Pinot Noir (Willamette Valley)
column3: The Estate Vineyard bottling shows a definite meaty, almost Rhone-like aroma, but this is no Syrah. It's a very elegant, light, sultry bottle of Pinot Noir. The tart black cherry and currant fruit is shadowed by smoke and cinnamon, but the balance throughout is light and delicate.

column2: Chehalem 2011 Ridgecrest Vineyards Pinot Noir (Ribbon Ridge)
column3: Proving that exceptional wines can be (and were) made in this cool, light vintage, this estate-grown selection is both elegant and complex. Flavors of mixed wild berries, a streak of tea, a whiff of peach and compelling balance carry it through an extended finish.

column2: Roco 2013 Wits' End Vineyard Pinot Noir (Chehalem Mountains)
column3: The regular bottling from the estate vineyard takes the spotlight in 2013, with a lightness and delicacy that in no way means it is simple or insubstantial. There's much to admire, from the silky cherry fruit to the dusty traces of sandalwood, saffron and butter brickle.
column9: I'd like a red wine, excluding Chardonnay.","

column2: Magnificent Wine Company 2007 House Wine Red (Columbia Valley (WA))
column3: An all-purpose red wine, blending seven different grapes into a fruit bowl of forward berry flavors. Nothing challenging here, but the fruit is tasty and it might be compared to a nice Beaujolais—chill it and drink it outdoors on a hot summer day.

column2: Red Theory 2012 Winemaker's Red (Columbia Valley (WA))
column3: A straightforward wine with light notes of red and blue berries along with oak accents.

column2: Château de Saint-Martin 2014 Cuvée Grande Réserve Rosé (Côtes de Provence)
column3: This is a pale-colored wine, very fruity and crisp with an impressively refreshing quality. A touch of pepper gives interest to this dry, easy-drinking wine.

column2: Tagaris 2007 Frank Chiullino Chef Blend Red Red (Columbia Valley (WA))
column3: This red wine, named for the chef at the winery restaurant, is fruity and high-toned, with lots of cherry and berry flavor. All neutral oak, soft tannins, ready to drink.

column2: Convergence Zone 2011 Squall Line Red (Red Mountain)
column3: This soft red wine discloses pomegranate fruit and a liberal amount of Mediterranean herbs. It's light and easy-sipping, and should be consumed while young.
column9: Suggest a wine from a winery known for its innovative practices.,

column2: Patz & Hall 2014 Chenoweth Ranch Pinot Noir (Russian River Valley)
column3: This lovely, memorable wine from a fantastically farmed site is grippy in cherry and pomegranate with a backbone of integrated oak. Crunchy in texture, it shines in floral aromatics and a balanced body weight that's fruity and complex.

column2: Chehalem 2011 Ridgecrest Vineyards Pinot Noir (Ribbon Ridge)
column3: Proving that exceptional wines can be (and were) made in this cool, light vintage, this estate-grown selection is both elegant and complex. Flavors of mixed wild berries, a streak of tea, a whiff of peach and compelling balance carry it through an extended finish.

column2: Peace Water 2012 Sublime Pinot Noir (Russian River Valley)
column3: Based in Carmel, this producer ventures north to Napa and Sonoma for grapes. It crafts this earthy, ethereal wine from Russian River fruit and donates part of its sales proceeds to a handful of charities. Mushroom, licorice, tea and cherry are all well-represented, wrapped in a conservative idling of oak.

column2: Moshin 2013 Calliope Vineyard Pinot Noir (Russian River Valley)
column3: This vineyard-designate pushes the envelope in terms of ripeness, opting to go for a restrained, low-alcohol style. It retains a streak of menthol through a juicy red core of strawberry and oak-toasted tannin, finishing lean.

column2: Joseph Swan Vineyards 2013 Great Oak Vineyard Suicide Hill Pinot Noir (Russian River Valley)
column3: This wine is produced in microscopic amounts, the result of sourcing grapes from a notoriously difficult-to-farm site. It rewards in flavor: hearty cherry and pomegranate fruit, a crisp, crunchy texture, powerful tannins and oak, and an underlying minerality that presents as elusively as a cloud of fog.
column9: What's a good red wine with a good balance between acidity and richness?,

column2: Château Sénéjac 2010 Barrel sample  (Haut-Médoc)
column3: 89-91 Balanced wine, its acidity marking the red berry fruits. It has a dry, tough core, while the fruit rolls easily through the structure.

column2: Domaine Parigot 2013 Les Peuillets Premier Cru  (Savigny-lès-Beaune)
column3: This ripe and soft wine has a great balance between the rich red berry fruits, bright cherries and acidity. The structure is full, generous and gives the wine a comfortable feel. Acidity at the end lends a fresher aspect. Drink from 2017.

column2: Domaine de la Ferté 2008 Servoisine Premier Cru  (Givry)
column3: With some richness, red fruits over wood and a full-bodied structure, this is a solid, dense wine. Acidity is present, while the ripe juicy fruits more than balance it. The tannins offer a firm structure and suggest aging.

column2: Quinta das Tecedeiras 2005 Reserva Red (Douro)
column3: A fine, balanced wine that brings out good toastiness alongside sweet, ripe fruit. Well made, showing good balance, with acidity giving a lift to all the richness. The aftertaste is rounded and delicious.

column2: Pierre André 2009 En Chevret  (Volnay)
column3: Rich, intense red-fruited wine, soft and voluptuous. The tannins are folded into the ripe fruits, giving a very approachable feel. The acidity is prominent at this stage but should soften in a year or two, and the wine is certainly worth aging.
column9: Can you suggest a wine from Spain?,

column2: Vicente Gandia 2013 Boâbrisa Red (Alentejo)
column3: Spanish producer Vicente Gandia continues its venture into Portugal with this ripe, spicy and toasty wine. Wood flavors mingle with the red fruits and bright acidity. It is rich, full and ready to drink.

column2: Viña Albali 2004 Reserva Tempranillo (Valdepeñas)
column3: A mature, more traditional Spanish wine that's ready to drink. The nose mixes tomato leaf, mint and maturing berry aromas, while the starchy, grabby palate shows aging raspberry and strawberry fruit with ample leather and dryness. Caramel, vanilla and toast notes grace the finish.

column2: Vicente Gandia 2012 Boâbrisa Red (Alentejano)
column3: Spanish producer Vicente Gandia has made a foray into Portugal with this ripely fruity and soft wine. It is fresh, herbal and spicy with attractive red berry fruits. It's been made to be drunk young and it's ready now.

column2: Casca Wines 2015 Monte Cascas Colheita Red (Alentejano)
column3: This smooth, rich wine exudes southern warmth. The blend of Touriga Nacional, Aragonez and Alicante Bouschet gives a ripe, dark-colored wine dominated by black fruits. Tannins and acidity provide happy support. Drink now.

column2: Herdade do Esporão 2014 Arco do Esporão Red (Alentejo)
column3: Touriga Nacional, Syrah and Aragonez (aka Tempranillo) give this wine a fine balance between structure and fruitiness. While the alcohol suggests power, in fact it's the freshness and attractive red berry fruits that dominate. The wine is soft and ready to drink.
column9: Recommend a wine with hints of floral.,

column2: Principi di Porcìa 2008 Ca' Bembo Pinot Grigio (Friuli Grave)
column3: Floral notes of honeysuckle and acacia ride on the heels of peach and nectarine. This is a simple white wine with good freshness and a lean, watery feel in the mouth.

column2: Corvo 2011 Glicine Red (Sicilia)
column3: This opens with floral aromas of violet and rose bud, followed by light berry and plum notes. The palate tastes easy and fresh.

column2: I Custodi 2013 Alnus Red (Etna)
column3: Pretty floral aromas with whiffs of red berry and savory herb take shape in the glass. Flinty mineral, pink grapefruit and a hint of baking spice back up the red cherry core.

column2: Lechthaler 2014 Torre di Luna Pinot Grigio (Trentino)
column3: This uber-informal wine has faint aromas that recall pressed wildflower and a whiff of pear. The simple, diluted palate shows hints of apple skin and a bitter medicinal note alongside brisk acidity.

column2: Massi di Mandorlaia 2012 Carbonile  (Morellino di Scansano)
column3: This delightful wine opens with notes of blue flower and ripe red berries that carry over to the palate. It makes a warm, soft accompaniment to everyday fare such as hearty pastas or dense Tuscan soups.
column9: I prefer dry winesany recommendations for both red and white?,

column2: Collegiale des Domaines de Loire 2014 Les Bois de Vaux Sec  (Vouvray)
column3: This bone-dry wine offers flavors of white fruits. Its crisp acidity is tempered by a touch of honey and spicy almonds. Balanced and fruity, the wine is ready to drink.

column2: Domaine Pichot 2015 Coteau de la Biche Sec  (Vouvray)
column3: This dry wine shows hints of honey as well as pure sliced apple and white stone fruits. It is deliciously crisp, bright with acidity, almonds and a tangy texture. The wine is totally ready to drink in its fruity youth.

column2: Château de Fesles 2014 La Chapelle Vieilles Vignes Chenin Blanc (Anjou)
column3: This bone-dry, fresh wine is crisp with citrus and apple flavors. There are touches of wood aging that adds spice to the tangy acidity and touches of honey. Perfumed and bright at the end, the wine is ready to drink.

column2: Château Moncontour 2012 Demi-Sec  (Vouvray)
column3: As the label says, the wine is off dry, but with its great, refreshing acidity, it is also crisp and fruity. Baked apples and citrus flavors mingle with a lightly mineral texture to give a lively, fragrant wine. Drink now.

column2: Domaine Vincent Carême 2011 Le Peu Morier  (Vouvray)
column3: Barely off dry, this wine is rich and very perfumed, hinting at an attractive light oxidation from the wood aging. Almonds, white fruits and a fine, tight texture round it out. It will age, so drink from 2014.
column9: I'm looking for a white wine with a floral aroma and a touch of sweetness. Any recommendations?,

column2: Trabucco 2008 16 Marzo White (Falerno del Massico)
column3: This is an herbal, floral white wine with aromas that span from dried hay to pungent lemon blossom. It seems to give the best of itself on the bouquet, because in the mouth, this wine is fresh, compact and very easygoing.

column2: Gancia NV Grand Reale White (Piedmont)
column3: Here is a sweet and fragrant dessert wine with aromas of white flower, honey and stone fruit accented by a slightly drying mineral characteristic. Firm, tonic effervescence keeps the palate refreshed even when paired with whipped cream or creamy fruit desserts.

column2: Adalia 2015 Singan  (Soave)
column3: Here's a light-bodied casual wine that has subdued aromas suggesting white flower, orchard fruit and a hint of almond. You can find traces of the nose on the extremely simple diluted palate.

column2: Cesari 2015 Cento Filari  (Lugana)
column3: White spring flower and citrus aromas lead the way on this juicy, savory wine. On the bright palate, a touch of cake spice accents succulent grapefruit, lemon drop and green apple alongside fresh acidity. A white almond note fills in the finish.

column2: Firriato 2016 Le Sabbie dell'Etna Bianco  (Etna)
column3: This wine's white flower, apple, pear and almond aromas carry over to its medium-bodied palate, along with a hint of citrus peel. It's linear and fresh, with bright acidity and a saline note on the close.
column9: Looking for a wine that is single-vineyard.,

column2: Boheme 2009 English Hill Vineyard Pinot Noir (Sonoma Coast)
column3: This single-vineyard wine is a little plodding and direct now. It's dry and acidic, with high-toned flavors of cranberry and sour cherry candy that turn heavy and seemingly sweet as you swallow.

column2: Tamarack Cellars 2010 Ciel du Cheval Vineyard Syrah (Red Mountain)
column3: Displaying exceptional single grape/single vineyard particularity, this tight and focused wine delivers pinpoint flavors of berries, berries and more berries. Light streaks of cola, earth and baking spices bring further complexity and interest. Drink now or cellar through 2024.

column2: Iota Cellars 2011 Pelos Sandberg Vineyard Pinot Noir (Eola-Amity Hills)
column3: This winery makes just a single, estate-grown Pinot Noir each year. Pomegranate and red plum fruit flavors are gracefully showcased in this elegant vintage. Silky and smooth, it retains focus through a medium-weight, impeccably clean finish.

column2: College Cellars 2012 Cockburn Ranch Vineyard Syrah (Walla Walla Valley (WA))
column3: This single-vineyard wine offers wild blueberry with vanilla and herb accents. It's full bodied and high-octane in feel with the flavors running straight down the fairway.

column2: Kudos 2014 Zena Crown Vineyard Pinot Noir (Eola-Amity Hills)
column3: Tight and tannic, this single-vineyard offering emphasizes flavors of herb, grass and green leaf. There's a hint of pale, generic red fruit, but it's more in the veggie camp—think rhubarb rather than raspberry. A hint of brown sugar rounds out the finish.
column9: Suggest a wine from a winery known for its historic practices.,

column2: Tiago Teles 2012 Gilda Red (Bairrada)
column3: An earthy wine that has red berry fruits and acidity alongside a rustic barnyard character. There is a mineral edge to the wine as well, so maybe giving it a year will help.

column2: Josetta Saffirio 2008 Millenovecento 48 Riserva  (Barolo)
column3: Made from vines planted in 1948, this brawny wine opens with aromas of toasted oak, espresso, black plum, violet and a whiff of leather. The palate offers coffee, chocolate, sage, toast and a hint of black cherry alongside drying wood tannins.

column2: Contratto 2003 Cerequio  (Barolo)
column3: The celebrated Cerequio cru is known for its elegant and refined wines. However, in this hot vintage, you can taste the maturity of the fruit thanks to the wine's aromas of plum, prune and spice cake. Clay soils help shape the wine's natural density and structure.

column2: Marchesi di Barolo 2008 Cannubi  (Barolo)
column3: In this vintage, this historic wine shows a different personality with its ripe aromas of blackberry and raspberry jam. It opens with notes of spice, tobacco and black pepper.

column2: Casa Santos Lima 2015 Stones & Bones Red (Lisboa)
column3: The name of this wine comes from the landscape of the vineyard with its ancient rocks and fossilized remains. It is soft, smooth and spicy, with bold, ripe flavors and a touch of vanilla from the wood aging. This is generous, full of fruit and ready to drink.
column9: I'm interested in a wine from the Champagne region.,

column2: Gremillet NV Blanc de Noirs Brut Pinot Noir (Champagne)
column3: Hailing from the southern Aube region, where Pinot Noir ripens well, this Champagne is rich and full, with hints of red fruit, zesty orange and lemon-tinged minerality. The acidity is bright and fruity, highlighting the wine's attractive texture. Drink now.

column2: Fluteau 2008 Cuvée Symbiose Brut  (Champagne)
column3: This impressive Champagne is rich while tight and mineral-textured. Creamy and ripe, it balances the weight of Pinot Noir with the elegance of Chardonnay. The producer's location in the relatively warm Aube region gives its wines extra fullness. This one is just now ready to drink.

column2: Jean Laurent 2003 Blanc de Noirs Millésime Brut Pinot Noir (Champagne)
column3: With the dominance of Pinot Noir in the Aube region, it is no surprise to find a vintage Champagne that is 100% from that grape. With a round character from the Pinot, as well as a hot vintage, this is a full-bodied wine with vibrant fruit and lively acidity. Drink now.

column2: Drappier 2008 Grande Sendrée Rosé Brut  (Champagne)
column3: This is a beautiful wine with its pink-orange color. The taste lives up to its appearance. A mature wine from a great vintage, it's rich with spice and nuts along with tight acidity. From fruit grown in the southern Champagne region of the Aube, the wine is completely ready to drink.

column2: Faniel et Fils NV Agapane Brut  (Champagne)
column3: This is the entry-level wine from this producer based in the Marne Valley. That's the land of Pinot Meunier and this Champagne contains 74% of the grape, giving a soft rounded wine. It has delicious acidity with citrus and red-berry fruit and a lightly crisp texture that is balanced by the soft ripe aftertaste. Drink now.
column9: Can you suggest a wine from Australia?,

column2: Cullen 2013 Kevin John Chardonnay (Margaret River)
column3: It's a shame only the equivalent of one barrel of this wine was exported to the U.S., as it means only a handful of people here will get to experience it. It's perhaps the closest thing to great white Burgundy to come from Australia; subtly smoky at first, like grilled white peaches, adding hints of lime and vanilla on the palate. It's plump and slightly creamy in texture, but finishes with crisp, acidic verve. Drink now–2025.

column2: Wise 2005 Eagle Bay Shiraz (Margaret River)
column3: From Margaret River in Western Australia, this is a full-bodied, impressively endowed Shiraz at a reasonable price. Superripe aromas of blackberries and licorice mark the nose, while the palate features similar flavors, supple tanins and a creamy-textured finish. Good to go now, with enough concentration to hold until 2015.

column2: Maverick 2014 Breechens Shiraz (Barossa)
column3: It's hard to believe such a wine can come from the Barossa, a region known for size and richness. But this is part of a new wave of Aussie Shiraz—medium in body and silky in style, with moderate alcohol levels. Healthy doses of oak impart notes of hickory smoke, cedar and vanilla to the plum fruit. Drink now–2025.

column2: Wirra Wirra 2012 Catapult Shiraz (McLaren Vale)
column3: Representative of the solid values that may be found from Australia for about $20, this medium- to full-bodied Shiraz offers a blend of cherry and plum flavors, with savory elements of mocha and roasted meat. It's slightly dusty on the finish, making it food-friendly, ending with hints of cocoa and coffee. Drink now–2018.

column2: Shingleback NV Black Bubbles Sparkling Shiraz (McLaren Vale)
column3: A sleek name and a sleek wine. Vanilla and toffee overflow from the effusive nose while sour candy and plum jam take over on the palate. It's a tad thin in the mouth but finishes on a lovely raspberry note that has just a bit of sticking power. Drink as the Australians do, with Christmas dinner. Sparkling Shiraz may not be something you pour every day, but this is one worth reaching for. It delivers lots of upfront berry fruit and lashings of dark chocolate, then finishes relatively dry and clean.
column9: I'm interested in a wine from the Bordeaux region.,

column2: Barrière Frères 2006 Jacques Sans Souci  (Bordeaux)
column3: A wine that aims to bring out the casual side of Bordeaux, this is friendly, accessible, without losing the essential dry tannins and fresh black currant flavors typical of the region. If only all branded Bordeaux was like this.

column2: Maison Bouey 2010 Les Parcelles de Stéphane Derenoncourt  (Haut-Médoc)
column3: This selection from eight parcels of vines was made by one of the top Bordeaux consultants. The result is a ripe, warm wine that has great swathes of plum fruits alongside some firm, dry tannins. It is rich while retaining plenty of fresh acidity. Drink now.

column2: Château le Pré de la Lande 2004 Réserve de la Famille  (Sainte-Foy Bordeaux)
column3: From the far eastern edge of Bordeaux, this wine offers delicious, fresh fruits structured by light tannins. Its black currant flavors are right up front, pleasure without complications.
column7: Château le Pré de la Lande

column2: Les Vignerons Réunis de Monségur 2014 Château le Mayne Turon  (Bordeaux)
column3: Grown in the far eastern edge of Bordeaux, in the Entre-deux-Mers, this is a bright and fruity wine. It has tannins that just lift the juicy red and black-currant fruits.

column2: Domaines Barons de Rothschild (Lafite) 2005 Réserve Spéciale  (Bordeaux)
column3: A structured, firm wine showing a great balance of red fruits, dry Bordeaux-style tannins and a freshly jammy texture. For a branded Bordeaux, it has both quality and elegance.
column9: What would be a good wine for a dinner party?,

column2: Bellini 2008 VYD Red (Toscana)
column3: This is a very informal and easygoing red table wine that would taste great with pizza. It opens with a bright ruby color and shows aromas of cherry, raspberry and toasted almond.

column2: Castello di Montegiove 2010 Gatto Gatto  (Orvieto)
column3: Sometimes you need a light and refreshing red wine to serve with burgers or franks. This informal wine from Umbria shows an easy bouquet that is characterized by black fruit, bacon and cured meat.

column2: Magnificent Wine Company 2007 House Wine Red (Columbia Valley (WA))
column3: An all-purpose red wine, blending seven different grapes into a fruit bowl of forward berry flavors. Nothing challenging here, but the fruit is tasty and it might be compared to a nice Beaujolais—chill it and drink it outdoors on a hot summer day.

column2: Feudo Antico 2008 Tullum Red (Abruzzo)
column3: This hearty red wine from central Italy would pair well with grilled meat or veal wrapped in sage leaves and sliced prosciutto ham. Loads of red berries are followed by notes of exotic spice, leather, tobacco and firm tannins. Drink in 3–5 more years.

column2: Convergence Zone 2011 Squall Line Red (Red Mountain)
column3: This soft red wine discloses pomegranate fruit and a liberal amount of Mediterranean herbs. It's light and easy-sipping, and should be consumed while young.
column9: Are there any white wines known for their mineral or flinty characteristics?,

column2: Fournier Père et Fils 2014 Cuvée Silex  (Sancerre)
column3: Grown on flinty soil, this strongly mineral-driven wine is structured, tense with acidity and white stone-fruit flavors. The initial crispness opens out into a concentrated, textured wine that will need to age further. Drink from late 2017.

column2: Domaine Fouassier 2008 Les Chailloux  (Sancerre)
column3: The name, referring to the flinty soil of the vineyard, says it all. It is a mineral wine that tastes of stony soil, flint and chalk. It has a great core of hardened steel, very firm, surrounded by intense green fruits, filled with apple juice and grapefruit flavors. For aging over 2–3 years.

column2: Henri Bourgeois 2010 La Chapelle des Augustins  (Sancerre)
column3: The flint and sand soil of this vineyard brings out the minerally, steely character of this taut, tight wine. While it is herbaceous and flavors of pineapple and white fruit, the structure dominates. Give this impressive wine another year or two.

column2: Henri Bourgeois 2010 La Demoiselle de Bourgeois  (Pouilly-Fumé)
column3: Dominated by minerality, this is a flinty and steel textured wine. It has some richness while remaining straight and narrow. With its structured character, it will need to age for over several years.

column2: Fournier Père et Fils 2013 Cuvée Silex  (Sancerre)
column3: From vines grown on flint soil, this is a perfumed, crisp wine, hinting at almonds and spice. The background is a reminder of the soil, very mineral and severe. The wine is ready to drink.
column9: I'm looking for a white wine that's crisp and has a green apple taste. Any ideas?,

column2: Barton & Guestier 2015 Passeport Lobster & Shrimp  (Muscadet)
column3: A light and crisp wine that has a creamed apple texture. It is fruity, light with a fine citrus tang to add to the general freshness of the wine. The name suggests a very appropriate pairing.

column2: Château de la Ragotiere 2012 Sur Lie  (Muscadet Sèvre et Maine)
column3: This wine has great swathes of green fruits, like biting into a crisp apple. It's bright, shimmering with citrus and grapefruit. There is a tight, mineral bite at the end.

column2: Remy-Pannier 2012 Sur Lie  (Muscadet Sèvre et Maine)
column3: Fruity and tangy, this is a light and fresh wine. It has crisp green apples patterned with citrus fruits and a tight, bright texture. Ready to drink.

column2: La Vis 2014 Simboli Pinot Grigio (Trentino)
column3: Bright and refreshing, this easygoing white offers delicate aromas and flavors of white spring flower, Granny Smith apple and citrus. Racy acidity gives it a crisp finish.

column2: Domaine du Haut Bourg 2014 Sur Lie  (Muscadet Côtes de Grandlieu)
column3: Light and fresh, this is an apple-crisp wine with delicious acidity and a refreshing lemon tang. A finely textured character gives shape to the wine and supports the crunchy fruit. Drink this wine now.
column9: Looking for a wine that is aged in oak barrels.,

column2: Château Grand Mayne 2012 Barrel Sample  (Saint-Émilion)
column3: 91–93. Barrel sample. This spicy wine, aged in new wood, is rich and full with blackberry flavors. It's opulent in texture with layers of new oak that reverberate through the wine.

column2: Château Caronne Ste Gemme 2012 Barrel Sample  (Haut-Médoc)
column3: 87–89. Barrel sample. This is a warm, open wine that's gently tannic, and likely to age quickly. It has some spice, ripe black plums, and aftertaste that reveals some of its dry structure.

column2: Château Providence 2012 Barrel Sample  (Pomerol)
column3: 92–94. Barrel sample. This is a ripe and smoky wine with lively acidity. It also has dense black fruits and a firmly tannic character that demands aging. Solid in texture, it's touched by notes of licorice with a bitter edge.

column2: Château d'Arcins 2012 Barrel Sample  (Haut-Médoc)
column3: 85–87. Barrel sample. This is a soft, simple wine. It has attractive, gentle fruits and some ripe tannins. Likely to age quickly.

column2: Château Cambon la Pelouse 2012 Barrel Sample  (Haut-Médoc)
column3: 90–92. Barrel sample. This is a ripe and spicy wine that showcases flavors of new wood and rich, sweet black fruits. The wine is attractive and fruity, but with enough structure to promise some good aging.
column9: Suggest a wine from a winery known for its small-batch practices.,

column2: Talisman 2014 Huckleberry's Vineyard Pinot Noir (Sonoma Coast)
column3: From a vineyard that's less than one acre in size, this special bottling is tiny but mighty, juicy in blue and red fruit. Robust in spice, it unleashes a velvety texture with ease, allowing room for focused tannin to be supportive rather than distracting. The finish retains a welcome freshness.

column2: David Hill 2009 Estate Pinot Noir (Willamette Valley)
column3: This is the winery's budget offering. It shows modest varietal flavors, with a slight burned or roasted character.

column2: Love & Squalor 2014 Sunny Mountain Vineyard Pinot Noir (Willamette Valley)
column3: Small production (one barrel!) single-vineyard Pinots are challenging, as there is no wiggle room via blending. This comes out crisp and focused, with light cherry fruit and ample flavors of tea, herb and leaf.

column2: The Withers Winery 2013 English Hill Pinot Noir (Sonoma Coast)
column3: Made by David Low of Anthill Farms in extremely small quantities, this is a new brand devoted to light-bodied wines from fine, cool-climate sites. Tight in dried cranberry and cherry, this is indeed a light and subtle undertaking, dusty and perfumed in rosewater fragrance.

column2: Fulcrum 2013 Gap's Crown Vineyard Pinot Noir (Sonoma Coast)
column3: Made in tiny quantities, this wine opens with aromas of crisp, just-peeled orange before unveiling silky tannins and a bite of oak. Light in color, it builds up layers of dark cherry, sage and mushroomy earth as it develops, with a substantial kick of texture and weight on the finish.
column9: I'm interested in a wine from the Tuscany region.,

column2: Vignamaggio 2008 Il Morino Sangiovese (Toscana)
column3: A great deal from Tuscany, this bright Sangiovese-based wine offers playful aromas of cassis, cherry and wild berry with red rose and a touch of toasted almond.

column2: Collemassari 2007 Riserva  (Montecucco)
column3: Some lovely red wines are coming from the Montecucco wine region (located in coastal Tuscany) and Collemassari leads the pack of this new and exciting group of vintners. Soft cherry, leather, spice, and earthy mineral tones create harmony and momentum.

column2: La Togata 2008 Azzurreta Sangiovese (Toscana)
column3: Hailing from the Montalcino area of Tuscany, this Sangiovese-based wine offers crisp nuances of white cherry and cassis, backed by touches of savory spice and bitter almond. The palate is clean, polished and silky.

column2: La Calonica 2009 Calcinaio Sangiovese (Cortona)
column3: From the Cortona area of eastern Tuscany, here is a simple, bright and crisp expression of Sangiovese that would pair with grilled meat or sausage.

column2: Col d'Orcia 2011 Spezieri Red (Toscana)
column3: This easy going blended red from Tuscany opens with bright cherry and blackberry aromas against a backdrop of bitter almond and a touch of Indian spice. The fresh acidity makes this a perfect pasta wine.
column9: What red wines would you recommend for someone who enjoys a velvety mouthfeel?,

column2: Balletto 2014 BCD Vineyard Estate Grown Estate Bottled Pinot Noir (Russian River Valley)
column3: Velvety-smooth and rich in red plum and strawberry, this medium-bodied, varietally honest wine is textured and complex. It's well-crafted and balanced, with a lingering finish.

column2: Caccia al Piano 1868 2009 Ruit Hora  (Bolgheri)
column3: Merlot (70%), Cabernet Sauvignon and Petit Verdot make for a smooth and rich wine with candied fruit, blueberry, spice and loads of sweet cherry. It's chewy and tight in the mouth, with polished, almost squeaky tannins and impressive length.

column2: Chime NV Schatz Family Vineyard Red (California)
column3: Easygoing and soft in texture, this medium-bodied red wine has fruity, jammy aromas and flavors, and blends in a little black pepper for interest.

column2: Barrel Road 2014 Artisan Blend Red (California)
column3: This light- to medium-bodied red wine doesn't take itself too seriously and will be versatile with food. The fruity, almost jammy and fresh aromas lead to dry, substantive flavors and a tempting, smooth texture.

column2: Casa di Terra 2011 Moreccio  (Bolgheri)
column3: Soft, round and pleasurable, this Syrah-Merlot-Cabernet Sauvignon blend would pair well with pastas or roasts. Bright cherry and blackberry flavors are followed by subtle leather and spice accents. The mouthfeel is fresh and fruity.
column9: What's a good full-bodied white wine that's not overly oaked?,

column2: Bogle 2013 Phantom Red (California)
column3: Pure and delicious, this generous, lightly spicy and velvet-textured wine does a great job of combining ripe, tasty fruit flavors with an enticing oaky layer that seems to bring subtle sweetness. While full bodied it is not heavy, and has firm, fine-grained tannins to add texture.

column2: Giant Steps 2013 Tarraford Vineyard Chardonnay (Yarra Valley)
column3: This reasonably full-bodied Chardonnay manages to retain a sense of freshness and crispness throughout. Subtle oak and vanilla notes frame peach and pineapple fruit, while the finish is long and citrusy clean.

column2: Bogle 2013 Essential Red (California)
column3: Welcoming and easy to drink, this full-bodied wine has mellow, ripe fruit flavors, light oaky accents and a warm sense of ripeness that doesn't go over the top. Subtle tannins support the texture while keeping it smooth. The blend includes Zinfandel, Syrah, Cabernet Sauvignon and Petite Sirah.

column2: Two Horns 2012 A Mean Red (California)
column3: Not too heavy or too rich, this medium-bodied wine has mellow spice and fruit flavors, good balance and a gentle texture. It will be perfect when you don't want to drink a blockbuster.

column2: Rare 2012 Black Blend Extremely Rare Red (California)
column3: This is an elegant, silky-textured wine that doesn't taste as black or bold as the label would suggest. It has medium body, bright fruit flavors and hints of white pepper and white chocolate that accent a core of red cherry and raspberry.
column9: I'm interested in a wine from the Napa Valley region.,

column2: Stag's Leap Wine Cellars 2012 S.L.V. Cabernet Sauvignon (Napa Valley)
column3: This estate-grown wine honors the historical vineyard that brought the Napa Valley worldwide attention for Cabernet. It offers both complexity and elegance, as well as an herbal underbrush accented by tobacco. Chocolate, caramel and coffee add to the intrigue around smooth, velvety tannins.

column2: Jamieson Ranch 2011 Double Lariat Cabernet Sauvignon (Napa Valley)
column3: A very nice wine, showcasing the Napa style of lush, plush opulence. It's softly tannic, with ripe blackberry, raspberry, mocha and cedar flavors. Not an ager—drink by 2015.

column2: Bell 2009 Claret Cabernet Sauvignon (Napa Valley)
column3: A very nice wine that shows the smooth, complex tannin structure, ripe fruit and dry balance you'd want from a Napa Valley Cabernet Sauvignon. You'll like the blackberry, cherry and cedar flavors, enhanced by touches of dried herb and cocoa. Drink now–2015 for fruity freshness.

column2: Hall 2012 Eighteen Seventy-Three Cabernet Sauvignon (Napa Valley)
column3: Opaque deep purple in color, this luxuriously rendered wine comes from the eastern Vaca range of the Napa Valley. It expands on the palate with a richness of plum, cinnamon, brown sugar and dark chocolate. Smooth and sturdy in tannin, it finishes with a taste of hazelnut.

column2: Phifer Pavitt 2011 Date Night Cabernet Sauvignon (Napa Valley)
column3: From grapes grown in Pope Valley, the eastern part of the Napa Valley, this is mostly Cabernet Sauvignon, with 2% Petit Verdot. Smoky bacon and thick, concentrated waves of blackberry mark the wine, which is made by Ted Osborne of Olabisi. The finish is dark and chocolaty, with more of that smoke.
column9: Recommend a wine with hints of cherry.,

column2: Cubanisimo Vineyards 2012 Rumba Pinot Noir (Willamette Valley)
column3: This is a light and cheery wine, with cherry and raspberry fruit. It suggests hard candy with a hint of the barnyard; forward, round and fruity.

column2: Bergström 2010 Shea Vineyard Pinot Noir
column3: Bright cherry fruit is set against a backdrop of clean earth, while the young tannins are firm and focused. The wine carries balanced suggestions of leaf and herb, and will surely benefit from further bottle age.

column2: Castelgiocondo 2012 Campo ai Sassi  (Rosso di Montalcino)
column3: This straightforward, simple wine brings together sensations of violet, red cherry and light baking spices. The warm, forward palate finishes on a sweet note of cherry extract. It's made to be enjoyed young and will pair well with hearty pasta dishes.

column2: Siduri 2006 Muirfield Vineyard Pinot Noir (Willamette Valley)
column3: Cherries jump out at you, a dense compendium of fruit set against iron and earth. The wine is a bit austere, tight; it may need decanting. But it's got good concentration and spice, and flavor that keeps on running through a long finish.

column2: Benton-Lane 2010 Estate Pinot Noir (Willamette Valley)
column3: A pretty, inviting nose suggests sweet cherry and cherry blossom. On the light-bodied palate, the wine shows earthiness. It's pleasant and just right for near-term enjoyment.
column9: I'm interested in trying a red wine with a subtle herbal or floral aroma. Any ideas?,

column2: Fattoria di Grignano 2011 Pietramaggio Red (Toscana)
column3: Here's a simple but well made red from Tuscany that has floral aromas of violet and rose with berry notes. The palate offers bright cherry, red currant and a touch of spice. Pair this with pasta dishes or grilled vegetables.

column2: Rivetto 2011 Cè Vanin  (Barbaresco)
column3: Fresh red rose, blue flower, bright red berry and baking spices lead the nose on this structured wine. The palate delivers juicy red cherry, cinnamon and white pepper alongside notes of mint and balsamic herbs. It's a bit austere with bracing tannins that need time to soften. Drink after 2017.

column2: Impostino 2012 Ciarlone  (Montecucco)
column3: This straightforward red offers subdued aromas of leather, white pepper and a balsamic note. The simple evolved palate offers red berry, green tea and a hint of clove alongside loose knit, rather fleeting tannins.

column2: Grimaldi Bruna 2013 Camilla  (Barolo)
column3: Intense aromas of rose, chopped aromatic herb and a balsamic note set the tone on this fragrant red. It's fresh and linear, offering sour cherry, clove and cranberry flavors framed in fine-grained tannins. Notes of espresso and sage add depth to the finish.

column2: Dezzani 2012 Stardè  (Barbaresco)
column3: Simple but solid, this offers delicate aromas of rose and red berry. The straightforward palate isn't as expressive, showing dried cherry, a note of star anise and sage alongside assertive astringent tannins that leave an abrupt, mouth-drying finish.
column9: What would be a good wine for a summer afternoon?,

column2: Ravoire et Fils 2016 Domaine Fontval Grenache-Mourvèdre Rosé (Mediterranée)
column3: This wine is soft and light. It has a gentle fruity character, with soft acidity. Well chilled on a hot day, this will be refreshing.

column2: Wines & Winemakers 2013 Dona Helena Colheita White (Península de Setúbal)
column3: This is a fine, simple wine for this summer. With acidity, fresh apple and pear flavors, it's attractive and aromatic.

column2: Union de Vignerons de l'Île de Beauté 2016 Terra Santa Rosé (Ile de Beauté)
column3: This light, fruity wine is a perfect summer apéritif. With a crisp texture and attractive red fruit, it's lively and refreshing. Drink now.
column7: Union de Vignerons de l'Île de Beauté

column2: Quintas de Melgaço 2015 Blue White (Vinho Verde)
column3: A deliciously fresh and soft young wine, it is just off dry: really more light and crisp. Lemon and tight citrus flavors are lifted by a prickle on the tongue. This is a perfect summer drink.

column2: Villa Cornaro 2011 Limited Selection Pinot Grigio (Veneto)
column3: This is one of those fun, easygoing Italian Pinot Grigios that tastes great on a hot summer afternoon. The wine is crisp, light and lean with simple endnotes of citrus and melon.
column9: What's a good medium-bodied red wine with earthy undertones?,

column2: Astrolabe 2014 Province Pinot Noir (Marlborough)
column3: This medium-bodied wine successfully blends several disparate notes into a harmonious whole. Hints of just-turned earth, cola, root vegetables, clove and fresh greens join on the nose, while the palate adds fruitier overtones of red cherries and berries. The tannins are silky, the acids vibrant.

column2: Uptick Vineyards 2011 Estate Pinot Noir (Russian River Valley)
column3: Unctuous and earthy, this medium-bodied wine is more about subtle and savory herb notes than deep fruit. With its light fruit characteristics and bold spice elements, it will make a versatile choice for the table.

column2: MacMurray Estate Vineyards 2013 Reserve Pinot Noir (Russian River Valley)
column3: Light in color and silky in texture, this earthy wine offers overtones of cinnamon, dark cherry, raspberry and clove. Well integrated in terms of oak and tannin, it's full-bodied enough to please those who like a bigger styled wine.

column2: Thomas George 2014 Estate Pinot Noir (Russian River Valley)
column3: A moderate level of earthiness is found in this approachable wine, which is friendly and rounded in baked cherry, plum, cola and velvety smooth layers of texture. It pleases for its brisk acidity and integrated oak.

column2: Hawley 2014 Oehlman Vineyard Pinot Noir (Russian River Valley)
column3: Earthy with subtle Asian spice and forest floor scents, this wine is medium in build and generous in tannin, still untangling its limbs in the glass.
column9: Can you suggest a white wine that's light-bodied and has a subtle floral aroma?,

column2: Adalia 2015 Singan  (Soave)
column3: Here's a light-bodied casual wine that has subdued aromas suggesting white flower, orchard fruit and a hint of almond. You can find traces of the nose on the extremely simple diluted palate.

column2: Trabucco 2008 16 Marzo White (Falerno del Massico)
column3: This is an herbal, floral white wine with aromas that span from dried hay to pungent lemon blossom. It seems to give the best of itself on the bouquet, because in the mouth, this wine is fresh, compact and very easygoing.

column2: Banear 2006 Mamàn White (Delle Venezie)
column3: A luminous Italian white wine offersing subdued tones of stone fruit, white mineral and honey. There's an aromatic component that is reminiscent of mint and the wine is clean and easy in the mouth with a vibrant, fresh finish.

column2: Firriato 2016 Le Sabbie dell'Etna Bianco  (Etna)
column3: This wine's white flower, apple, pear and almond aromas carry over to its medium-bodied palate, along with a hint of citrus peel. It's linear and fresh, with bright acidity and a saline note on the close.

column2: Salviano 2012 Salviano  (Orvieto Classico)
column3: Here's a delightful and straightforward wine that opens with a delicate fragrance of white spring flowers. The palate offers notes of tropical fruit, lemon zest and a hint of clove. It has a clean, quenching finish.
column9: Looking for a wine that is limited edition.,

column2: Chehalem 2014 Statement Pinot Noir (Ribbon Ridge)
column3: Only occasionally produced, this reserve-level wine is a bit of a mystery in this new vintage. It's tart and shy, its black fruit laced with assertive acidity and its finish excessively astringent.

column2: Chehalem 2011 Ridgecrest Vineyards Pinot Noir (Ribbon Ridge)
column3: Proving that exceptional wines can be (and were) made in this cool, light vintage, this estate-grown selection is both elegant and complex. Flavors of mixed wild berries, a streak of tea, a whiff of peach and compelling balance carry it through an extended finish.

column2: Belle Vallée 2006 Grand Cuvée Pinot Noir (Willamette Valley)
column3: This is the winery's most limited offering, with exotic aromas of musk, saffron and sandalwood. It fills the midpalate with soft red fruits and more of those floral highlights, then turns slightly soapy and tannic.

column2: King Estate 2013 Antiquum Vineyards Pinot Noir (Willamette Valley)
column3: This delivers handmade, natural wine character. It's a limited release from King's “Vineyard Designate” series, and a bold, deep, supple and smooth one at that. Red plum, citrus peel, a thread of caramel and a whiff of chocolate combine in a wine that should drink well through 2026.

column2: Johan 2012 Three Barrel Pinot Noir (Willamette Valley)
column3: As the name indicates, this limited reserve is a selection of the winemaker's best barrels. It was fermented with 90% whole clusters, and aged 15 months in one-third new French oak. There are ample scents and flavors of stem, leaf and root, which dominate. Give this wine a lot of breathing time or a vigorous decant, which will help to bring the fruit back up.
column9: Can you suggest a red wine that's bold but not overly tannic?,

column2: Quinta do Casal Monteiro 2010 Colheita Seleccionada Red (Tejo)
column3: A rich and fruity wine, it's not subtle, but is full of spice and red berry flavors. Firm tannins underpin the bright, bold flavors and suggest that this is a wine that could age for a few years but is also very enjoyable now.

column2: Sogrape 2012 Herdade do Peso Vinhha do Monte Red (Alentejano)
column3: A bold, fruity and juicy wine that is softly ripe. The tannins are well integrated into the black fruits and acidity. It's not a wine that needs to age.

column2: Château de Lisennes 2011 Cuvée Tradition  (Bordeaux Supérieur)
column3: This bold, fruity wine is all red berries and ripe cherry flavors. It has good juiciness, soft tannins and it will be ready to drink soon. A bright wine, with great acidity at the end.

column2: Caymus 2014 Special Selection Cabernet Sauvignon (Napa Valley)
column3: Brawny tannins meet mild acidity in this powerful, rich wine that's full-bodied and decadent. Chocolate, mocha and caramel notes are etched into its soft, rounded layers of generous red fruit.

column2: Poças 2003 Coroa D'ouro Reserva Red (Douro)
column3: A soft, simple wine, the tannins set the pace, but the fruit doesn't quite follow. It is relatively light, with some red fruits and good acidity.
